scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in Cleopatra's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Philo
dialogues.line: Nay, but this dotage of our general's O'erflows the measure. Those his goodly eyes, That o'er the files and musters of the war Have glowed like plated Mars, now bend, now turn The office and devotion of their view Upon a tawny front. His captain's heart, Which in the scuffles of great fights hath burst The buckles on his breast, reneges all temper And is become the bellows and the fan To cool a gipsy's lust. Flourish. Enter Antony and Cleopatra, her Ladies, the Train, with Eunuchs fanning her. Look where they come: Take but good note, and you shall see in him The triple pillar of the world transform'd Into a strumpet's fool. Behold and see.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: If it be love indeed, tell me how much.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: There's beggary in the love that can be reckoned.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I'll set a bourn how far to be beloved.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Then must thou needs find out new heaven, new earth.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: News, my good lord, from Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Grates me, the sum.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Nay, hear them, Antony. Fulvia perchance is angry; or who knows If the scarce-bearded Caesar have not sent His powerful mandate to you: "Do this or this; Take in that kingdom and enfranchise that. Perform't, or else we damn thee."

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: How, my love?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Perchance! Nay, and most like. You must not stay here longer; your dismission Is come from Caesar; therefore hear it, Antony. Where's Fulvia's process?-Caesar's I would say? Both? Call in the messengers. As I am Egypt's queen, Thou blushest, Antony, and that blood of thine Is Caesar's homager; else so thy cheek pays shame When shrill-tongued Fulvia scolds. The messengers!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Let Rome in Tiber melt, and the wide arch Of the ranged empire fall! Here is my space. Kingdoms are clay. Our dungy earth alike Feeds beast as man. The nobleness of life Is to do thus ; when such a mutual pair And such a twain can do't, in which I bind, On pain of punishment, the world to weet We stand up peerless.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Excellent falsehood! Why did he marry Fulvia, and not love her? I'll seem the fool I am not. Antony Will be himself.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: But stirred by Cleopatra. Now, for the love of Love and her soft hours, Let's not confound the time with conference harsh. There's not a minute of our lives should stretch Without some pleasure now. What sport tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Hear the ambassadors.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Fie, wrangling queen! Whom everything becomes-to chide, to laugh, To weep; whose every passion fully strives To make itself, in thee fair and admired! No messenger but thine, and all alone Tonight we'll wander through the streets and note The qualities of people. Come, my queen, Last night you did desire it. Speak not to us.

dialogues.speaker: Demetrius
dialogues.line: Is Caesar with Antonius prized so slight?

dialogues.speaker: Philo
dialogues.line: Sir, sometimes when he is not Antony, He comes too short of that great property Which still should go with Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Demetrius
dialogues.line: I am full sorry That he approves the common liar who Thus speaks of him at Rome, but I will hope Of better deeds tomorrow. Rest you happy!

scenes.location: Alexandria. Another Room in Cleopatra's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Lord Alexas, sweet Alexas, most anything Alexas, almost most absolute Alexas, where's the soothsayer that you praised so to th' queen? O, that I knew this husband which you say must charge his horns with garlands!

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Soothsayer!

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Your will?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Is this the man? Is't you, sir, that know things?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: In nature's infinite book of secrecy A little I can read.

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Show him your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Bring in the banquet quickly; wine enough Cleopatra's health to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Good, sir, give me good fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: I make not, but foresee.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Pray, then, foresee me one.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: You shall be yet far fairer than you are.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: He means in flesh.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: No, you shall paint when you are old.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Wrinkles forbid!

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Vex not his prescience. Be attentive.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Hush!

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: You shall be more beloving than beloved.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: I had rather heat my liver with drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Nay, hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Good now, some excellent fortune! Let me be married to three kings in a forenoon and widow them all. Let me have a child at fifty, to whom Herod of Jewry may do homage. Find me to marry me with Octavius Caesar, and companion me with my mistress.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: You shall outlive the lady whom you serve.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: O, excellent! I love long life better than figs.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: You have seen and proved a fairer former fortune Than that which is to approach.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Then belike my children shall have no names. Prithee, how many boys and wenches must I have?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: If every of your wishes had a womb, And fertile every wish, a million.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Out, fool! I forgive thee for a witch.

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: You think none but your sheets are privy to your wishes.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Nay, come, tell Iras hers.

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: We'll know all our fortunes.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Mine, and most of our fortunes tonight, shall be drunk to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: There's a palm presages chastity, if nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: E'en as the o'erflowing Nilus presageth famine.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Go, you wild bedfellow, you cannot soothsay.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Nay, if an oily palm be not a fruitful prognostication, I cannot scratch mine ear. Prithee, tell her but workaday fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Your fortunes are alike.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: But how, but how? give me particulars.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: I have said.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Am I not an inch of fortune better than she?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Well, if you were but an inch of fortune better than I, where would you choose it?

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Not in my husband's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Our worser thoughts heavens mend! Alexas-come, his fortune! his fortune! O, let him marry a woman that cannot go, sweet Isis, I beseech thee, and let her die too, and give him a worse, and let worse follow worse, till the worst of all follow him laughing to his grave, fiftyfold a cuckold! Good Isis, hear me this prayer, though thou deny me a matter of more weight; good Isis, I beseech thee!

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Amen. Dear goddess, hear that prayer of the people! For, as it is a heartbreaking to see a handsome man loose-wived, so it is a deadly sorrow to behold a foul knave uncuckolded. Therefore, dear Isis, keep decorum and fortune him accordingly!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Lo now, if it lay in their hands to make me a cuckold, they would make themselves whores but they'd do't!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Hush, Here comes Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Not he, the queen.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Saw you my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: No, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Was he not here?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: No, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: He was disposed to mirth; but on the sudden A Roman thought hath struck him. Enobarbus!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Madam?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Seek him and bring him hither. Where's Alexas?

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Here, at your service. My lord approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: We will not look upon him. Go with us.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Fulvia thy wife first came into the field.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Against my brother Lucius.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Ay. But soon that war had end, and the time's state Made friends of them, jointing their force 'gainst Caesar, Whose better issue in the war from Italy Upon the first encounter drave them.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Well, what worst?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The nature of bad news infects the teller.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: When it concerns the fool or coward. On. Things that are past are done with me. 'Tis thus: Who tells me true, though in his tale lie death, I hear him as he flattered.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Labienus- This is stiff news-hath with his Parthian force Extended Asia from Euphrates His conquering banner shook from Syria To Lydia and to Ionia, Whilst-

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: "Antony", thou wouldst say-

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: O, my lord!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Speak to me home; mince not the general tongue. Name Cleopatra as she is called in Rome; Rail thou in Fulvia's phrase, and taunt my faults With such full licence as both truth and malice Have power to utter. O, then we bring forth weeds When our quick minds lie still, and our ills told us Is as our earing. Fare thee well awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: At your noble pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: From Sicyon, ho, the news? Speak there!

dialogues.speaker: Second Messenger
dialogues.line: The man from Sicyon-

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Is there such a one?

dialogues.speaker: Second Messenger
dialogues.line: He stays upon your will.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Let him appear. These strong Egyptian fetters I must break, Or lose myself in dotage. What are you?

dialogues.speaker: Third Messenger
dialogues.line: Fulvia thy wife is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Where died she?

dialogues.speaker: Third Messenger
dialogues.line: In Sicyon: Her length of sickness, with what else more serious Importeth thee to know, this bears.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Forbear me. There's a great spirit gone! Thus did I desire it. What our contempts doth often hurl from us, We wish it ours again. The present pleasure, By revolution lowering, does become The opposite of itself. She's good, being gone. The hand could pluck her back that shoved her on. I must from this enchanting queen break off. Ten thousand harms, more than the ills I know, My idleness doth hatch. How now, Enobarbus!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: What's your pleasure, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I must with haste from hence.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Why then we kill all our women. We see how mortal an unkindness is to them. If they suffer our departure, death's the word.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I must be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Under a compelling occasion, let women die. It were pity to cast them away for nothing, though, between them and a great cause they should be esteemed nothing. Cleopatra, catching but the least noise of this, dies instantly. I have seen her die twenty times upon far poorer moment. I do think there is mettle in death which commits some loving act upon her, she hath such a celerity in dying.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: She is cunning past man's thought.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Alack, sir, no; her passions are made of nothing but the finest part of pure love. We cannot call her winds and waters sighs and tears; they are greater storms and tempests than almanacs can report. This cannot be cunning in her; if it be, she makes a shower of rain as well as Jove.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Would I had never seen her!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: O, sir, you had then left unseen a wonderful piece of work, which not to have been blest withal would have discredited your travel.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Fulvia is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Fulvia is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Fulvia?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Why, sir, give the gods a thankful sacrifice. When it pleaseth their deities to take the wife of a man from him, it shows to man the tailors of the earth; comforting therein that when old robes are worn out, there are members to make new. If there were no more women but Fulvia, then had you indeed a cut, and the case to be lamented. This grief is crowned with consolation; your old smock brings forth a new petticoat: and indeed the tears live in an onion that should water this sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: The business she hath broached in the state Cannot endure my absence.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: And the business you have broached here cannot be without you, especially that of Cleopatra's, which wholly depends on your abode.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: No more light answers. Let our officers Have notice what we purpose. I shall break The cause of our expedience to the Queen, And get her leave to part. For not alone The death of Fulvia, with more urgent touches, Do strongly speak to us, but the letters too Of many our contriving friends in Rome Petition us at home. Sextus Pompeius Hath given the dare to Caesar, and commands The empire of the sea. Our slippery people, Whose love is never linked to the deserver Till his deserts are past, begin to throw Pompey the Great and all his dignities Upon his son, who, high in name and power, Higher than both in blood and life, stands up For the main soldier; whose quality, going on, The sides o' th' world may danger. Much is breeding Which, like the courser's hair, hath yet but life And not a serpent's poison. Say our pleasure To such whose place is under us, requires Our quick remove from hence.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I shall do't.

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in Cleopatra's palace.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: I did not see him since.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: See where he is, who's with him, what he does. I did not send you. If you find him sad, Say I am dancing; if in mirth, report That I am sudden sick. Quick, and return.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Madam, methinks, if you did love him dearly, You do not hold the method to enforce The like from him.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What should I do I do not?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: In each thing give him way; cross him in nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Thou teachest like a fool: the way to lose him.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Tempt him not so too far; I wish, forbear. In time we hate that which we often fear. But here comes Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I am sick and sullen.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I am sorry to give breathing to my purpose-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Help me away, dear Charmian! I shall fall. It cannot be thus long; the sides of nature Will not sustain it.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Now, my dearest queen-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Pray you, stand farther from me.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I know by that same eye there's some good news. What, says the married woman you may go? Would she had never given you leave to come! Let her not say 'tis I that keep you here. I have no power upon you; hers you are.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: The gods best know-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O, never was there queen So mightily betrayed! Yet at the first I saw the treasons planted.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Cleopatra-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Why should I think you can be mine and true, Though you in swearing shake the throned gods, Who have been false to Fulvia? Riotous madness, To be entangled with those mouth-made vows Which break themselves in swearing!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Most sweet queen-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Nay, pray you seek no colour for your going, But bid farewell and go. When you sued staying, Then was the time for words. No going then, Eternity was in our lips and eyes, Bliss in our brows' bent; none our parts so poor But was a race of heaven. They are so still, Or thou, the greatest soldier of the world, Art turned the greatest liar.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: How now, lady!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I would I had thy inches, thou shouldst know There were a heart in Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Hear me, queen: The strong necessity of time commands Our services awhile, but my full heart Remains in use with you. Our Italy Shines o'er with civil swords; Sextus Pompeius Makes his approaches to the port of Rome; Equality of two domestic powers Breed scrupulous faction; the hated, grown to strength, Are newly grown to love; the condemned Pompey, Rich in his father's honour, creeps apace Into the hearts of such as have not thrived Upon the present state, whose numbers threaten; And quietness, grown sick of rest, would purge By any desperate change. My more particular, And that which most with you should safe my going, Is Fulvia's death.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Though age from folly could not give me freedom, It does from childishness. Can Fulvia die?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: She's dead, my queen. Look here, and at thy sovereign leisure read The garboils she awaked; at the last, best, See when and where she died.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O most false love! Where be the sacred vials thou shouldst fill With sorrowful water? Now I see, I see, In Fulvia's death how mine received shall be.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Quarrel no more, but be prepared to know The purposes I bear; which are, or cease, As you shall give th' advice. By the fire That quickens Nilus' slime, I go from hence Thy soldier, servant, making peace or war As thou affects.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Cut my lace, Charmian, come! But let it be; I am quickly ill and well, So Antony loves.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: My precious queen, forbear, And give true evidence to his love, which stands An honourable trial.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: So Fulvia told me. I prithee, turn aside and weep for her, Then bid adieu to me, and say the tears Belong to Egypt. Good now, play one scene Of excellent dissembling, and let it look Like perfect honour.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: You'll heat my blood. No more.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: You can do better yet, but this is meetly.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Now, by my sword-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: And target. Still he mends. But this is not the best. Look, prithee, Charmian, How this Herculean Roman does become The carriage of his chafe.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I'll leave you, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Courteous lord, one word. Sir, you and I must part, but that's not it; Sir, you and I have loved, but there's not it; That you know well. Something it is I would- O, my oblivion is a very Antony, And I am all forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: But that your royalty Holds idleness your subject, I should take you For idleness itself.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: 'Tis sweating labour To bear such idleness so near the heart As Cleopatra this. But, sir, forgive me, Since my becomings kill me when they do not Eye well to you. Your honour calls you hence; Therefore be deaf to my unpitied folly, And all the gods go with you! Upon your sword Sit laurel victory, and smooth success Be strewed before your feet!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Let us go. Come. Our separation so abides and flies That thou, residing here, goes yet with me, And I, hence fleeting, here remain with thee. Away!

scenes.location: Rome. An Apartment in Caesar's House.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: You may see, Lepidus, and henceforth know, It is not Caesar's natural vice to hate Our great competitor. From Alexandria This is the news: he fishes, drinks, and wastes The lamps of night in revel: is not more manlike Than Cleopatra, nor the queen of Ptolemy More womanly than he; hardly gave audience, or Vouchsafed to think he had partners. You shall find there A man who is the abstract of all faults That all men follow.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: I must not think there are Evils enough to darken all his goodness. His faults in him seem as the spots of heaven, More fiery by night's blackness; hereditary Rather than purchased; what he cannot change Than what he chooses.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: You are too indulgent. Let's grant it is not Amiss to tumble on the bed of Ptolemy, To give a kingdom for a mirth, to sit And keep the turn of tippling with a slave, To reel the streets at noon, and stand the buffet With knaves that smell of sweat. Say this becomes him- As his composure must be rare indeed Whom these things cannot blemish-yet must Antony No way excuse his foils when we do bear So great weight in his lightness. If he filled His vacancy with his voluptuousness, Full surfeits and the dryness of his bones Call on him for't. But to confound such time That drums him from his sport, and speaks as loud As his own state and ours, 'tis to be chid As we rate boys who, being mature in knowledge, Pawn their experience to their present pleasure And so rebel to judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Here's more news.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Thy biddings have been done, and every hour, Most noble Caesar, shalt thou have report How 'tis abroad. Pompey is strong at sea, And it appears he is beloved of those That only have feared Caesar. To the ports The discontents repair, and men's reports Give him much wronged.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I should have known no less. It hath been taught us from the primal state That he which is was wished until he were, And the ebbed man, ne'er loved till ne'er worth love, Comes deared by being lacked. This common body, Like to a vagabond flag upon the stream, Goes to and back, lackeying the varying tide, To rot itself with motion.

dialogues.speaker: Second Messenger
dialogues.line: Caesar, I bring thee word Menecrates and Menas, famous pirates, Make the sea serve them, which they ear and wound With keels of every kind. Many hot inroads They make in Italy-the borders maritime Lack blood to think on't-and flush youth revolt. No vessel can peep forth but 'tis as soon Taken as seen; for Pompey's name strikes more Than could his war resisted.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Antony, Leave thy lascivious wassails. When thou once Was beaten from Modena, where thou slew'st Hirtius and Pansa, consuls, at thy heel Did famine follow, whom thou fought'st against, Though daintily brought up, with patience more Than savages could suffer. Thou didst drink The stale of horses and the gilded puddle Which beasts would cough at. Thy palate then did deign The roughest berry on the rudest hedge. Yea, like the stag when snow the pasture sheets, The barks of trees thou browsed. On the Alps It is reported thou didst eat strange flesh Which some did die to look on. And all this- It wounds thine honour that I speak it now- Was borne so like a soldier that thy cheek So much as lanked not.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: 'Tis pity of him.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Let his shames quickly Drive him to Rome. 'Tis time we twain Did show ourselves i' th' field, and to that end Assemble we immediate council. Pompey Thrives in our idleness.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Tomorrow, Caesar, I shall be furnished to inform you rightly Both what by sea and land I can be able To front this present time.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Till which encounter It is my business too. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Farewell, my lord. What you shall know meantime Of stirs abroad, I shall beseech you, sir, To let me be partaker.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Doubt not, sir. I knew it for my bond.

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Charmian!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Madam?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Ha, ha! Give me to drink mandragora.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Why, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: That I might sleep out this great gap of time My Antony is away.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: You think of him too much.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O, 'tis treason!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Madam, I trust not so.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Thou, eunuch Mardian!

dialogues.speaker: Mardian
dialogues.line: What's your highness' pleasure?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Not now to hear thee sing. I take no pleasure In aught an eunuch has. 'Tis well for thee That, being unseminared, thy freer thoughts May not fly forth of Egypt. Hast thou affections?

dialogues.speaker: Mardian
dialogues.line: Yes, gracious madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Indeed?

dialogues.speaker: Mardian
dialogues.line: Not in deed, madam, for I can do nothing But what indeed is honest to be done. Yet have I fierce affections, and think What Venus did with Mars.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O, Charmian, Where think'st thou he is now? Stands he, or sits he? Or does he walk? Or is he on his horse? O happy horse, to bear the weight of Antony! Do bravely, horse, for wot'st thou whom thou mov'st? The demi-Atlas of this earth, the arm And burgonet of men. He's speaking now, Or murmuring "Where's my serpent of old Nile?" For so he calls me. Now I feed myself With most delicious poison. Think on me That am with Phœbus' amorous pinches black, And wrinkled deep in time? Broad-fronted Caesar, When thou wast here above the ground, I was A morsel for a monarch. And great Pompey Would stand and make his eyes grow in my brow; There would he anchor his aspect, and die With looking on his life.

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Sovereign of Egypt, hail!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: How much unlike art thou Mark Antony! Yet, coming from him, that great medicine hath With his tinct gilded thee. How goes it with my brave Mark Antony?

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Last thing he did, dear queen, He kissed-the last of many doubled kisses- This orient pearl. His speech sticks in my heart.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Mine ear must pluck it thence.

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: "Good friend," quoth he, "Say, the firm Roman to great Egypt sends This treasure of an oyster; at whose foot, To mend the petty present, I will piece Her opulent throne with kingdoms. All the east, Say thou, shall call her mistress." So he nodded And soberly did mount an arm-gaunt steed, Who neighed so high that what I would have spoke Was beastly dumbed by him.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What, was he sad or merry?

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Like to the time o' th' year between the extremes Of hot and cold, he was nor sad nor merry.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O well-divided disposition!-Note him, Note him, good Charmian, 'tis the man; but note him: He was not sad, for he would shine on those That make their looks by his; he was not merry, Which seemed to tell them his remembrance lay In Egypt with his joy; but between both. O heavenly mingle!-Be'st thou sad or merry, The violence of either thee becomes, So does it no man else.-Met'st thou my posts?

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Ay, madam, twenty several messengers. Why do you send so thick?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Who's born that day When I forget to send to Antony Shall die a beggar.-Ink and paper, Charmian.- Welcome, my good Alexas.-Did I, Charmian, Ever love Caesar so?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: O that brave Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Be choked with such another emphasis! Say "the brave Antony."

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: The valiant Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: By Isis, I will give thee bloody teeth If thou with Caesar paragon again My man of men.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: By your most gracious pardon, I sing but after you.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: My salad days, When I was green in judgment, cold in blood, To say as I said then. But come, away, Get me ink and paper. He shall have every day a several greeting, Or I'll unpeople Egypt.

scenes.location: Messina. A Room in Pompey's house.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: If the great gods be just, they shall assist The deeds of justest men.

dialogues.speaker: Menecrates
dialogues.line: Know, worthy Pompey, That what they do delay they not deny.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Whiles we are suitors to their throne, decays The thing we sue for.

dialogues.speaker: Menecrates
dialogues.line: We, ignorant of ourselves, Beg often our own harms, which the wise powers Deny us for our good; so find we profit By losing of our prayers.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I shall do well. The people love me, and the sea is mine; My powers are crescent, and my auguring hope Says it will come to th' full. Mark Antony In Egypt sits at dinner, and will make No wars without doors. Caesar gets money where He loses hearts. Lepidus flatters both, Of both is flattered; but he neither loves Nor either cares for him.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Caesar and Lepidus Are in the field. A mighty strength they carry.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Where have you this? 'Tis false.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: From Silvius, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: He dreams. I know they are in Rome together, Looking for Antony. But all the charms of love, Salt Cleopatra, soften thy waned lip! Let witchcraft join with beauty, lust with both; Tie up the libertine in a field of feasts; Keep his brain fuming. Epicurean cooks Sharpen with cloyless sauce his appetite, That sleep and feeding may prorogue his honour Even till a Lethe'd dullness- How now, Varrius!

dialogues.speaker: Varrius
dialogues.line: This is most certain that I shall deliver: Mark Antony is every hour in Rome Expected. Since he went from Egypt 'tis A space for farther travel.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I could have given less matter A better ear.-Menas, I did not think This amorous surfeiter would have donned his helm For such a petty war. His soldiership Is twice the other twain. But let us rear The higher our opinion, that our stirring Can from the lap of Egypt's widow pluck The ne'er lust-wearied Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: I cannot hope Caesar and Antony shall well greet together. His wife that's dead did trespasses to Caesar; His brother warred upon him, although I think, Not moved by Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I know not, Menas, How lesser enmities may give way to greater. Were't not that we stand up against them all, 'Twere pregnant they should square between themselves, For they have entertained cause enough To draw their swords. But how the fear of us May cement their divisions, and bind up The petty difference, we yet not know. Be't as our gods will have't! It only stands Our lives upon to use our strongest hands. Come, Menas.

scenes.location: Rome. A Room in the House of Lepidus.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Good Enobarbus, 'tis a worthy deed, And shall become you well, to entreat your captain To soft and gentle speech.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I shall entreat him To answer like himself. If Caesar move him, Let Antony look over Caesar's head And speak as loud as Mars. By Jupiter, Were I the wearer of Antonius' beard, I would not shave't today.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: 'Tis not a time For private stomaching.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Every time Serves for the matter that is then born in't.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: But small to greater matters must give way.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Not if the small come first.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Your speech is passion; But pray you stir no embers up. Here comes The noble Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: And yonder Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: If we compose well here, to Parthia. Hark, Ventidius.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I do not know, Maecenas. Ask Agrippa.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Noble friends, That which combined us was most great, and let not A leaner action rend us. What's amiss, May it be gently heard. When we debate Our trivial difference loud, we do commit Murder in healing wounds. Then, noble partners, The rather for I earnestly beseech, Touch you the sourest points with sweetest terms, Nor curstness grow to th' matter.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: 'Tis spoken well. Were we before our armies, and to fight, I should do thus.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Welcome to Rome.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Sit.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Sit, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Nay, then.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I learn you take things ill which are not so, Or being, concern you not.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I must be laughed at If, or for nothing or a little, I Should say myself offended, and with you Chiefly i' th' world; more laughed at that I should Once name you derogately when to sound your name It not concerned me.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: My being in Egypt, Caesar, What was't to you?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: No more than my residing here at Rome Might be to you in Egypt. Yet if you there Did practise on my state, your being in Egypt Might be my question.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: How intend you, practised?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: You may be pleased to catch at mine intent By what did here befall me. Your wife and brother Made wars upon me, and their contestation Was theme for you; you were the word of war.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: You do mistake your business. My brother never Did urge me in his act. I did inquire it, And have my learning from some true reports That drew their swords with you. Did he not rather Discredit my authority with yours, And make the wars alike against my stomach, Having alike your cause? Of this my letters Before did satisfy you. If you'll patch a quarrel, As matter whole you have not to make it with, It must not be with this.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: You praise yourself By laying defects of judgment to me; but You patched up your excuses.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Not so, not so. I know you could not lack-I am certain on't- Very necessity of this thought, that I, Your partner in the cause 'gainst which he fought, Could not with graceful eyes attend those wars Which fronted mine own peace. As for my wife, I would you had her spirit in such another. The third o' th' world is yours, which with a snaffle You may pace easy, but not such a wife.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Would we had all such wives, that the men Might go to wars with the women.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: So much uncurbable, her garboils, Caesar, Made out of her impatience-which not wanted Shrewdness of policy too-I grieving grant Did you too much disquiet. For that you must But say I could not help it.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I wrote to you When rioting in Alexandria; you Did pocket up my letters, and with taunts Did gibe my missive out of audience.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Sir, He fell upon me ere admitted, then. Three kings I had newly feasted, and did want Of what I was i' th' morning. But next day I told him of myself, which was as much As to have asked him pardon. Let this fellow Be nothing of our strife; if we contend, Out of our question wipe him.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: You have broken The article of your oath, which you shall never Have tongue to charge me with.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Soft, Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: No, Lepidus, let him speak. The honour is sacred which he talks on now, Supposing that I lacked it. But on, Caesar: The article of my oath?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: To lend me arms and aid when I required them, The which you both denied.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Neglected, rather; And then when poisoned hours had bound me up From mine own knowledge. As nearly as I may I'll play the penitent to you. But mine honesty Shall not make poor my greatness, nor my power Work without it. Truth is that Fulvia, To have me out of Egypt, made wars here, For which myself, the ignorant motive, do So far ask pardon as befits mine honour To stoop in such a case.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: 'Tis noble spoken.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: If it might please you to enforce no further The griefs between ye; to forget them quite Were to remember that the present need Speaks to atone you.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Worthily spoken, Maecenas.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Or, if you borrow one another's love for the instant, you may, when you hear no more words of Pompey, return it again. You shall have time to wrangle in when you have nothing else to do.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Thou art a soldier only. Speak no more.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: That truth should be silent I had almost forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: You wrong this presence; therefore speak no more.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Go to, then. Your considerate stone!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I do not much dislike the matter, but The manner of his speech; for't cannot be We shall remain in friendship, our conditions So differing in their acts. Yet if I knew What hoop should hold us staunch, from edge to edge O' th' world I would pursue it.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Give me leave, Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Speak, Agrippa.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Thou hast a sister by the mother's side, Admired Octavia. Great Mark Antony Is now a widower.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Say not so, Agrippa. If Cleopatra heard you, your reproof Were well deserved of rashness.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I am not married, Caesar. Let me hear Agrippa further speak.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: To hold you in perpetual amity, To make you brothers, and to knit your hearts With an unslipping knot, take Antony Octavia to his wife; whose beauty claims No worse a husband than the best of men; Whose virtue and whose general graces speak That which none else can utter. By this marriage All little jealousies, which now seem great, And all great fears, which now import their dangers, Would then be nothing. Truths would be tales, Where now half-tales be truths. Her love to both Would each to other, and all loves to both, Draw after her. Pardon what I have spoke, For 'tis a studied, not a present thought, By duty ruminated.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Will Caesar speak?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Not till he hears how Antony is touched With what is spoke already.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: What power is in Agrippa, If I would say "Agrippa, be it so," To make this good?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: The power of Caesar, and His power unto Octavia.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: May I never To this good purpose, that so fairly shows, Dream of impediment! Let me have thy hand. Further this act of grace; and from this hour The heart of brothers govern in our loves And sway our great designs!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: There's my hand. A sister I bequeath you, whom no brother Did ever love so dearly. Let her live To join our kingdoms and our hearts; and never Fly off our loves again!

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Happily, amen!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I did not think to draw my sword 'gainst Pompey, For he hath laid strange courtesies and great Of late upon me. I must thank him only, Lest my remembrance suffer ill report; At heel of that, defy him.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Time calls upon 's. Of us must Pompey presently be sought, Or else he seeks out us.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Where lies he?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: About the Mount Misena.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: What is his strength by land?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Great and increasing; but by sea He is an absolute master.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: So is the fame. Would we had spoke together! Haste we for it. Yet, ere we put ourselves in arms, dispatch we The business we have talked of.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: With most gladness, And do invite you to my sister's view, Whither straight I'll lead you.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Let us, Lepidus, not lack your company.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Noble Antony, not sickness should detain me.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: Welcome from Egypt, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Half the heart of Caesar, worthy Maecenas! My honourable friend, Agrippa!

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Good Enobarbus!

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: We have cause to be glad that matters are so well digested. You stayed well by 't in Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Ay, sir, we did sleep day out of countenance and made the night light with drinking.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: Eight wild boars roasted whole at a breakfast, and but twelve persons there. Is this true?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: This was but as a fly by an eagle. We had much more monstrous matter of feast, which worthily deserved noting.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: She's a most triumphant lady, if report be square to her.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: When she first met Mark Antony, she pursed up his heart upon the river of Cydnus.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: There she appeared indeed, or my reporter devised well for her.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I will tell you. The barge she sat in, like a burnished throne, Burned on the water. The poop was beaten gold; Purple the sails, and so perfumed that The winds were love-sick with them; the oars were silver, Which to the tune of flutes kept stroke, and made The water which they beat to follow faster, As amorous of their strokes. For her own person, It beggared all description: she did lie In her pavilion, cloth-of-gold of tissue, O'erpicturing that Venus where we see The fancy outwork nature. On each side her Stood pretty dimpled boys, like smiling Cupids, With divers-coloured fans, whose wind did seem To glow the delicate cheeks which they did cool, And what they undid did.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: O, rare for Antony!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Her gentlewomen, like the Nereides, So many mermaids, tended her i' th' eyes, And made their bends adornings. At the helm A seeming mermaid steers. The silken tackle Swell with the touches of those flower-soft hands That yarely frame the office. From the barge A strange invisible perfume hits the sense Of the adjacent wharfs. The city cast Her people out upon her, and Antony, Enthroned i' th' market-place, did sit alone, Whistling to th' air, which, but for vacancy, Had gone to gaze on Cleopatra too, And made a gap in nature.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Rare Egyptian!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Upon her landing, Antony sent to her, Invited her to supper. She replied It should be better he became her guest, Which she entreated. Our courteous Antony, Whom ne'er the word of "No" woman heard speak, Being barbered ten times o'er, goes to the feast, And, for his ordinary, pays his heart For what his eyes eat only.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Royal wench! She made great Caesar lay his sword to bed. He ploughed her, and she cropped.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I saw her once Hop forty paces through the public street And, having lost her breath, she spoke and panted, That she did make defect perfection, And, breathless, pour breath forth.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: Now Antony must leave her utterly.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Never. He will not. Age cannot wither her, nor custom stale Her infinite variety. Other women cloy The appetites they feed, but she makes hungry Where most she satisfies. For vilest things Become themselves in her, that the holy priests Bless her when she is riggish.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: If beauty, wisdom, modesty can settle The heart of Antony, Octavia is A blessed lottery to him.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Let us go. Good Enobarbus, make yourself my guest Whilst you abide here.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Humbly, sir, I thank you.

scenes.location: Rome. A Room in Caesar's House.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: The world and my great office will sometimes Divide me from your bosom.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: All which time Before the gods my knee shall bow my prayers To them for you.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Good night, sir.-My Octavia, Read not my blemishes in the world's report. I have not kept my square, but that to come Shall all be done by th' rule. Good night, dear lady.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: Good night, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Now, sirrah, you do wish yourself in Egypt?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Would I had never come from thence, nor you thither!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: If you can, your reason.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: I see it in my motion, have it not in my tongue. But yet hie you to Egypt again.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Say to me, Whose fortunes shall rise higher, Caesar's or mine?

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: Caesar's. Therefore, O Antony, stay not by his side. Thy dæmon-that thy spirit which keeps thee-is Noble, courageous, high, unmatchable, Where Caesar's is not. But near him, thy angel Becomes afeard, as being o'erpowered. Therefore Make space enough between you.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Speak this no more.

dialogues.speaker: Soothsayer
dialogues.line: To none but thee; no more but when to thee. If thou dost play with him at any game, Thou art sure to lose; and of that natural luck He beats thee 'gainst the odds. Thy lustre thickens When he shines by. I say again, thy spirit Is all afraid to govern thee near him; But, he away, 'tis noble.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Get thee gone. Say to Ventidius I would speak with him. He shall to Parthia. Be it art or hap, He hath spoken true. The very dice obey him, And in our sports my better cunning faints Under his chance. If we draw lots, he speeds; His cocks do win the battle still of mine When it is all to naught, and his quails ever Beat mine, inhooped, at odds. I will to Egypt: And though I make this marriage for my peace, I' th' East my pleasure lies. O, come, Ventidius, You must to Parthia. Your commission's ready. Follow me and receive 't.

scenes.location: Rome. A street.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Trouble yourselves no further. Pray you hasten Your generals after.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Sir, Mark Antony Will e'en but kiss Octavia, and we'll follow.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Till I shall see you in your soldier's dress, Which will become you both, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: We shall, As I conceive the journey, be at the Mount Before you, Lepidus.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Your way is shorter; My purposes do draw me much about. You'll win two days upon me.

dialogues.speaker: Both
dialogues.line: Sir, good success!

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Farewell.

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Give me some music-music, moody food Of us that trade in love.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: The music, ho!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Let it alone. Let's to billiards. Come, Charmian.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: My arm is sore. Best play with Mardian.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: As well a woman with an eunuch played As with a woman. Come, you'll play with me, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Mardian
dialogues.line: As well as I can, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: And when good will is showed, though't come too short, The actor may plead pardon. I'll none now. Give me mine angle; we'll to the river. There, My music playing far off, I will betray Tawny-finned fishes. My bended hook shall pierce Their slimy jaws, and as I draw them up I'll think them every one an Antony, And say "Ah, ha! You're caught."

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: 'Twas merry when You wagered on your angling; when your diver Did hang a salt fish on his hook, which he With fervency drew up.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: That time?-O times!- I laughed him out of patience; and that night I laughed him into patience, and next morn, Ere the ninth hour, I drunk him to his bed, Then put my tires and mantles on him, whilst I wore his sword Philippan. O! from Italy! Ram thou thy fruitful tidings in mine ears, That long time have been barren.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Madam, madam-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Antony's dead! If thou say so, villain, Thou kill'st thy mistress. But well and free, If thou so yield him, there is gold, and here My bluest veins to kiss, a hand that kings Have lipped, and trembled kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: First, madam, he's well.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Why, there's more gold. But sirrah, mark, we use To say the dead are well. Bring it to that, The gold I give thee will I melt and pour Down thy ill-uttering throat.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Good madam, hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Well, go to, I will. But there's no goodness in thy face if Antony Be free and healthful. So tart a favour To trumpet such good tidings! If not well, Thou shouldst come like a Fury crowned with snakes, Not like a formal man.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Will't please you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I have a mind to strike thee ere thou speak'st. Yet if thou say Antony lives, is well, Or friends with Caesar, or not captive to him, I'll set thee in a shower of gold and hail Rich pearls upon thee.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Madam, he's well.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Well said.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: And friends with Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Th' art an honest man.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Caesar and he are greater friends than ever.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Make thee a fortune from me.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: But yet, madam-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I do not like "But yet", it does allay The good precedence. Fie upon "But yet"! "But yet" is as a gaoler to bring forth Some monstrous malefactor. Prithee, friend, Pour out the pack of matter to mine ear, The good and bad together: he's friends with Caesar, In state of health, thou say'st; and, thou say'st, free.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Free, madam? No. I made no such report. He's bound unto Octavia.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: For what good turn?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: For the best turn i' th' bed.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I am pale, Charmian.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Madam, he's married to Octavia.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: The most infectious pestilence upon thee!

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Good madam, patience.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What say you? Hence, horrible villain, or I'll spurn thine eyes Like balls before me! I'll unhair thy head! Thou shalt be whipped with wire and stewed in brine, Smarting in ling'ring pickle.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Gracious madam, I that do bring the news made not the match.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Say 'tis not so, a province I will give thee, And make thy fortunes proud. The blow thou hadst Shall make thy peace for moving me to rage, And I will boot thee with what gift beside Thy modesty can beg.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: He's married, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Rogue, thou hast lived too long.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Nay then I'll run. What mean you, madam? I have made no fault.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Good madam, keep yourself within yourself. The man is innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Some innocents 'scape not the thunderbolt. Melt Egypt into Nile, and kindly creatures Turn all to serpents! Call the slave again. Though I am mad, I will not bite him. Call!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: He is afeard to come.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I will not hurt him. These hands do lack nobility that they strike A meaner than myself, since I myself Have given myself the cause. Come hither, sir. Though it be honest, it is never good To bring bad news. Give to a gracious message An host of tongues, but let ill tidings tell Themselves when they be felt.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: I have done my duty.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Is he married? I cannot hate thee worser than I do If thou again say "Yes."

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: He's married, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: The gods confound thee! Dost thou hold there still!

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Should I lie, madam?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O, I would thou didst, So half my Egypt were submerged and made A cistern for scaled snakes! Go, get thee hence. Hadst thou Narcissus in thy face, to me Thou wouldst appear most ugly. He is married?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: I crave your highness' pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: He is married?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Take no offence that I would not offend you. To punish me for what you make me do Seems much unequal. He's married to Octavia.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O, that his fault should make a knave of thee That art not what thou'rt sure of! Get thee hence! The merchandise which thou hast brought from Rome Are all too dear for me. Lie they upon thy hand, And be undone by 'em!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Good your highness, patience.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: In praising Antony I have dispraised Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Many times, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I am paid for't now. Lead me from hence; I faint. O Iras, Charmian! 'Tis no matter. Go to the fellow, good Alexas, bid him Report the feature of Octavia, her years, Her inclination; let him not leave out The colour of her hair. Bring me word quickly. Let him for ever go-let him not, Charmian. Though he be painted one way like a Gorgon, The other way 's a Mars.  Bid you Alexas Bring me word how tall she is. Pity me, Charmian, But do not speak to me. Lead me to my chamber.

scenes.location: Near Misenum.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Your hostages I have, so have you mine, And we shall talk before we fight.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Most meet That first we come to words, and therefore have we Our written purposes before us sent, Which if thou hast considered, let us know If 'twill tie up thy discontented sword And carry back to Sicily much tall youth That else must perish here.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: To you all three, The senators alone of this great world, Chief factors for the gods: I do not know Wherefore my father should revengers want, Having a son and friends, since Julius Caesar, Who at Philippi the good Brutus ghosted, There saw you labouring for him. What was't That moved pale Cassius to conspire? And what Made the all-honoured, honest Roman, Brutus, With the armed rest, courtiers of beauteous freedom, To drench the Capitol, but that they would Have one man but a man? And that is it Hath made me rig my navy, at whose burden The angered ocean foams, with which I meant To scourge th' ingratitude that despiteful Rome Cast on my noble father.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Take your time.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Thou canst not fear us, Pompey, with thy sails. We'll speak with thee at sea. At land thou know'st How much we do o'ercount thee.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: At land indeed Thou dost o'ercount me of my father's house; But since the cuckoo builds not for himself, Remain in't as thou mayst.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Be pleased to tell us- For this is from the present-how you take The offers we have sent you.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: There's the point.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Which do not be entreated to, but weigh What it is worth embraced.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: And what may follow To try a larger fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: You have made me offer Of Sicily, Sardinia; and I must Rid all the sea of pirates; then to send Measures of wheat to Rome. This 'greed upon, To part with unhacked edges and bear back Our targes undinted. CAESAR, ANTONY, and LEPIDUS. That's our offer.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Know, then, I came before you here a man prepared To take this offer. But Mark Antony Put me to some impatience. Though I lose The praise of it by telling, you must know When Caesar and your brother were at blows, Your mother came to Sicily and did find Her welcome friendly.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I have heard it, Pompey, And am well studied for a liberal thanks Which I do owe you.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Let me have your hand. I did not think, sir, to have met you here.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: The beds i' th' East are soft; and thanks to you, That called me timelier than my purpose hither, For I have gained by 't.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Since I saw you last, There is a change upon you.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Well, I know not What counts harsh Fortune casts upon my face, But in my bosom shall she never come To make my heart her vassal.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Well met here.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I hope so, Lepidus. Thus we are agreed. I crave our composition may be written And sealed between us.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: That's the next to do.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: We'll feast each other ere we part, and let's Draw lots who shall begin.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: That will I, Pompey.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: No, Antony, take the lot. But, first or last, your fine Egyptian cookery Shall have the fame. I have heard that Julius Caesar Grew fat with feasting there.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: You have heard much.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I have fair meanings, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: And fair words to them.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Then so much have I heard. And I have heard Apollodorus carried-

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: No more of that. He did so.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: What, I pray you?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: A certain queen to Caesar in a mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I know thee now. How far'st thou, soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Well; And well am like to do, for I perceive Four feasts are toward.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Let me shake thy hand. I never hated thee. I have seen thee fight When I have envied thy behaviour.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Sir, I never loved you much, but I ha' praised ye When you have well deserved ten times as much As I have said you did.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Enjoy thy plainness; It nothing ill becomes thee. Aboard my galley I invite you all. Will you lead, lords? CAESAR, ANTONY, and LEPIDUS. Show's the way, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Thy father, Pompey, would ne'er have made this treaty.- You and I have known, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: At sea, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: We have, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: You have done well by water.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: And you by land.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I will praise any man that will praise me, though it cannot be denied what I have done by land.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Nor what I have done by water.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Yes, something you can deny for your own safety: you have been a great thief by sea.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: And you by land.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: There I deny my land service. But give me your hand, Menas. If our eyes had authority, here they might take two thieves kissing.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: All men's faces are true, whatsome'er their hands are.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: But there is never a fair woman has a true face.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: No slander. They steal hearts.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: We came hither to fight with you.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: For my part, I am sorry it is turned to a drinking. Pompey doth this day laugh away his fortune.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: If he do, sure he cannot weep 't back again.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: You have said, sir. We looked not for Mark Antony here. Pray you, is he married to Cleopatra?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Caesar's sister is called Octavia.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: True, sir. She was the wife of Caius Marcellus.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: But she is now the wife of Marcus Antonius.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Pray you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: 'Tis true.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Then is Caesar and he for ever knit together.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: If I were bound to divine of this unity, I would not prophesy so.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: I think the policy of that purpose made more in the marriage than the love of the parties.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I think so too. But you shall find the band that seems to tie their friendship together will be the very strangler of their amity. Octavia is of a holy, cold, and still conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Who would not have his wife so?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Not he that himself is not so; which is Mark Antony. He will to his Egyptian dish again. Then shall the sighs of Octavia blow the fire up in Caesar, and, as I said before, that which is the strength of their amity shall prove the immediate author of their variance. Antony will use his affection where it is. He married but his occasion here.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: And thus it may be. Come, sir, will you aboard? I have a health for you.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I shall take it, sir. We have used our throats in Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Come, let's away.

scenes.location: On board Pompey's Galley, lying near Misenum.

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: Here they'll be, man. Some o' their plants are ill-rooted already; the least wind i' th' world will blow them down.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servant
dialogues.line: Lepidus is high-coloured.

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: They have made him drink alms-drink.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servant
dialogues.line: As they pinch one another by the disposition, he cries out "no more", reconciles them to his entreaty and himself to th' drink.

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: But it raises the greater war between him and his discretion.

dialogues.speaker: Second Servant
dialogues.line: Why, this it is to have a name in great men's fellowship. I had as lief have a reed that will do me no service as a partisan I could not heave.

dialogues.speaker: First Servant
dialogues.line: To be called into a huge sphere, and not to be seen to move in 't, are the holes where eyes should be, which pitifully disaster the cheeks. A sennet sounded. Enter Caesar, Antony, Pompey, Lepidus, Agrippa, Maecenas, Enobarbus, Menas with other Captains.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Thus do they, sir: they take the flow o' th' Nile By certain scales i' th' pyramid; they know By th' height, the lowness, or the mean, if dearth Or foison follow. The higher Nilus swells, The more it promises. As it ebbs, the seedsman Upon the slime and ooze scatters his grain, And shortly comes to harvest.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: You've strange serpents there?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Ay, Lepidus.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Your serpent of Egypt is bred now of your mud by the operation of your sun; so is your crocodile.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: They are so.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Sit, and some wine! A health to Lepidus!

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: I am not so well as I should be, but I'll ne'er out.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Not till you have slept. I fear me you'll be in till then.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Nay, certainly, I have heard the Ptolemies' pyramises are very goodly things. Without contradiction I have heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Pompey, a word.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Say in mine ear what is 't?

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Forsake thy seat, I do beseech thee, captain, And hear me speak a word.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Forbear me till anon.- This wine for Lepidus!

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: What manner o' thing is your crocodile?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: It is shaped, sir, like itself, and it is as broad as it hath breadth. It is just so high as it is, and moves with it own organs. It lives by that which nourisheth it, and the elements once out of it, it transmigrates.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: What colour is it of?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Of its own colour too.

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: 'Tis a strange serpent.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: 'Tis so, and the tears of it are wet.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Will this description satisfy him?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: With the health that Pompey gives him, else he is a very epicure.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Go hang, sir, hang! Tell me of that? Away! Do as I bid you.-Where's this cup I called for?

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: If for the sake of merit thou wilt hear me, Rise from thy stool.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I think thou'rt mad. The matter?

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: I have ever held my cap off to thy fortunes.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Thou hast served me with much faith. What's else to say?- Be jolly, lords.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: These quicksands, Lepidus, Keep off them, for you sink.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Wilt thou be lord of all the world?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: What sayst thou?

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Wilt thou be lord of the whole world? That's twice.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: How should that be?

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: But entertain it, And though you think me poor, I am the man Will give thee all the world.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Hast thou drunk well?

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: No, Pompey, I have kept me from the cup. Thou art, if thou dar'st be, the earthly Jove. Whate'er the ocean pales or sky inclips Is thine, if thou wilt have't.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Show me which way.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: These three world-sharers, these competitors, Are in thy vessel. Let me cut the cable, And when we are put off, fall to their throats. All then is thine.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Ah, this thou shouldst have done And not have spoke on 't! In me 'tis villainy; In thee 't had been good service. Thou must know 'Tis not my profit that does lead mine honour; Mine honour it. Repent that e'er thy tongue Hath so betray'd thine act. Being done unknown, I should have found it afterwards well done, But must condemn it now. Desist, and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: For this, I'll never follow thy palled fortunes more. Who seeks, and will not take when once 'tis offered, Shall never find it more.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: This health to Lepidus!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Bear him ashore. I'll pledge it for him, Pompey.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Here's to thee, Menas!

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Enobarbus, welcome!

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Fill till the cup be hid.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: There's a strong fellow, Menas.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: 'A bears the third part of the world, man. Seest not?

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: The third part, then, is drunk. Would it were all, That it might go on wheels!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Drink thou. Increase the reels.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: This is not yet an Alexandrian feast.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: It ripens towards it. Strike the vessels, ho! Here is to Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I could well forbear't. It's monstrous labour when I wash my brain And it grows fouler.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Be a child o' the time.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Possess it, I'll make answer. But I had rather fast from all, four days, Than drink so much in one.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Ha, my brave emperor, Shall we dance now the Egyptian Bacchanals And celebrate our drink?

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: Let's ha't, good soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Come, let's all take hands Till that the conquering wine hath steeped our sense In soft and delicate Lethe.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: All take hands. Make battery to our ears with the loud music, The while I'll place you; then the boy shall sing. The holding every man shall beat as loud As his strong sides can volley. Music plays. Enobarbus places them hand in hand.

dialogues.speaker: The Song
dialogues.line: Come, thou monarch of the vine, Plumpy Bacchus with pink eyne! In thy vats our cares be drowned, With thy grapes our hairs be crowned. Cup us till the world go round, Cup us till the world go round!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What would you more? Pompey, good night. Good brother, Let me request you off. Our graver business Frowns at this levity.-Gentle lords, let's part. You see we have burnt our cheeks. Strong Enobarb Is weaker than the wine, and mine own tongue Splits what it speaks. The wild disguise hath almost Anticked us all. What needs more words. Good night. Good Antony, your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: I'll try you on the shore.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: And shall, sir. Give's your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Pompey
dialogues.line: O Antony, You have my father's house. But, what? We are friends. Come, down into the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Take heed you fall not. Menas, I'll not on shore.

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: No, to my cabin. These drums, these trumpets, flutes! What! Let Neptune hear we bid a loud farewell To these great fellows. Sound and be hanged, sound out!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Hoo, says 'a! There's my cap!

dialogues.speaker: Menas
dialogues.line: Hoo! Noble captain, come.

scenes.location: A plain in Syria.

dialogues.speaker: Ventidius
dialogues.line: Now, darting Parthia, art thou struck, and now Pleased Fortune does of Marcus Crassus' death Make me revenger. Bear the king's son's body Before our army. Thy Pacorus, Orodes, Pays this for Marcus Crassus.

dialogues.speaker: Silius
dialogues.line: Noble Ventidius, Whilst yet with Parthian blood thy sword is warm, The fugitive Parthians follow. Spur through Media, Mesopotamia, and the shelters whither The routed fly. So thy grand captain Antony Shall set thee on triumphant chariots, and Put garlands on thy head.

dialogues.speaker: Ventidius
dialogues.line: O Silius, Silius, I have done enough. A lower place, note well, May make too great an act. For learn this, Silius: Better to leave undone than by our deed Acquire too high a fame when him we serve's away. Caesar and Antony have ever won More in their officer, than person. Sossius, One of my place in Syria, his lieutenant, For quick accumulation of renown, Which he achieved by th' minute, lost his favour. Who does i' th' wars more than his captain can Becomes his captain's captain; and ambition, The soldier's virtue, rather makes choice of loss Than gain which darkens him. I could do more to do Antonius good, But 'twould offend him, and in his offence Should my performance perish.

dialogues.speaker: Silius
dialogues.line: Thou hast, Ventidius, that Without the which a soldier and his sword Grants scarce distinction. Thou wilt write to Antony?

dialogues.speaker: Ventidius
dialogues.line: I'll humbly signify what in his name, That magical word of war, we have effected; How, with his banners, and his well-paid ranks, The ne'er-yet-beaten horse of Parthia We have jaded out o' th' field.

dialogues.speaker: Silius
dialogues.line: Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Ventidius
dialogues.line: He purposeth to Athens, whither, with what haste The weight we must convey with 's will permit, We shall appear before him.-On there, pass along!

scenes.location: Rome. An Ante-chamber in Caesar's house.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: What, are the brothers parted?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: They have dispatched with Pompey; he is gone. The other three are sealing. Octavia weeps To part from Rome. Caesar is sad, and Lepidus, Since Pompey's feast, as Menas says, is troubled With the greensickness.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: 'Tis a noble Lepidus.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: A very fine one. O, how he loves Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Nay, but how dearly he adores Mark Antony!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Caesar? Why he's the Jupiter of men.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: What's Antony? The god of Jupiter.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Spake you of Caesar? How, the nonpareil!

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: O, Antony! O thou Arabian bird!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Would you praise Caesar, say "Caesar". Go no further.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Indeed, he plied them both with excellent praises.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: But he loves Caesar best, yet he loves Antony. Hoo! Hearts, tongues, figures, scribes, bards, poets, cannot Think, speak, cast, write, sing, number-hoo!- His love to Antony. But as for Caesar, Kneel down, kneel down, and wonder.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Both he loves.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
