dialogues.line: They are his shards, and he their beetle. So, This is to horse. Adieu, noble Agrippa.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Good fortune, worthy soldier, and farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: No further, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: You take from me a great part of myself. Use me well in't. Sister, prove such a wife As my thoughts make thee, and as my farthest bond Shall pass on thy approof. Most noble Antony, Let not the piece of virtue which is set Betwixt us, as the cement of our love To keep it builded, be the ram to batter The fortress of it. For better might we Have loved without this mean, if on both parts This be not cherished.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Make me not offended In your distrust.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I have said.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: You shall not find, Though you be therein curious, the least cause For what you seem to fear. So the gods keep you, And make the hearts of Romans serve your ends. We will here part.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Farewell, my dearest sister, fare thee well. The elements be kind to thee, and make Thy spirits all of comfort! Fare thee well.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: My noble brother!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: The April's in her eyes. It is love's spring, And these the showers to bring it on.-Be cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: Sir, look well to my husband's house, and-

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What, Octavia?

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: I'll tell you in your ear.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Her tongue will not obey her heart, nor can Her heart inform her tongue-the swan's-down feather, That stands upon the swell at the full of tide, And neither way inclines.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Will Caesar weep?

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: He has a cloud in 's face.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: He were the worse for that were he a horse; So is he, being a man.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Why, Enobarbus, When Antony found Julius Caesar dead, He cried almost to roaring, and he wept When at Philippi he found Brutus slain.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: That year, indeed, he was troubled with a rheum; What willingly he did confound he wailed, Believe 't, till I weep too.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: No, sweet Octavia, You shall hear from me still. The time shall not Outgo my thinking on you.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Come, sir, come, I'll wrestle with you in my strength of love. Look, here I have you, thus I let you go, And give you to the gods.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Adieu, be happy!

dialogues.speaker: Lepidus
dialogues.line: Let all the number of the stars give light To thy fair way!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Farewell, farewell!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Farewell!

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Where is the fellow?

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Half afeared to come.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Go to, go to. Come hither, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Alexas
dialogues.line: Good majesty, Herod of Jewry dare not look upon you But when you are well pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: That Herod's head I'll have! But how, when Antony is gone, Through whom I might command it?-Come thou near.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Most gracious majesty!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Didst thou behold Octavia?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Ay, dread queen.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Madam, in Rome I looked her in the face, and saw her led Between her brother and Mark Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Is she as tall as me?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: She is not, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Didst hear her speak? Is she shrill-tongued or low?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Madam, I heard her speak. She is low-voiced.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: That's not so good. He cannot like her long.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Like her? O Isis! 'Tis impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I think so, Charmian: dull of tongue and dwarfish! What majesty is in her gait? Remember, If e'er thou look'dst on majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: She creeps. Her motion and her station are as one. She shows a body rather than a life, A statue than a breather.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Is this certain?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Or I have no observance.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Three in Egypt Cannot make better note.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: He's very knowing; I do perceive't. There's nothing in her yet. The fellow has good judgment.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Excellent.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Guess at her years, I prithee.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Madam, She was a widow.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Widow! Charmian, hark!

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: And I do think she's thirty.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Bear'st thou her face in mind? Is't long or round?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Round even to faultiness.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: For the most part, too, they are foolish that are so. Her hair, what colour?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Brown, madam, and her forehead As low as she would wish it.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: There's gold for thee. Thou must not take my former sharpness ill. I will employ thee back again; I find thee Most fit for business. Go make thee ready; Our letters are prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: A proper man.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Indeed, he is so. I repent me much That so I harried him. Why, methinks, by him, This creature's no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Nothing, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: The man hath seen some majesty, and should know.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Hath he seen majesty? Isis else defend, And serving you so long!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I have one thing more to ask him yet, good Charmian. But 'tis no matter; thou shalt bring him to me Where I will write. All may be well enough.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: I warrant you, madam.

scenes.location: Athens. A Room in Antony's House.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Nay, nay, Octavia, not only that- That were excusable, that and thousands more Of semblable import-but he hath waged New wars 'gainst Pompey; made his will, and read it To public ear; Spoke scantly of me; when perforce he could not But pay me terms of honour, cold and sickly He vented them; most narrow measure lent me; When the best hint was given him, he not took 't, Or did it from his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: O, my good lord, Believe not all, or if you must believe, Stomach not all. A more unhappy lady, If this division chance, ne'er stood between, Praying for both parts. The good gods will mock me presently When I shall pray "O, bless my lord and husband!" Undo that prayer by crying out as loud "O, bless my brother!" Husband win, win brother, Prays and destroys the prayer; no midway 'Twixt these extremes at all.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Gentle Octavia, Let your best love draw to that point which seeks Best to preserve it. If I lose mine honour, I lose myself; better I were not yours Than yours so branchless. But, as you requested, Yourself shall go between's. The meantime, lady, I'll raise the preparation of a war Shall stain your brother. Make your soonest haste, So your desires are yours.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: Thanks to my lord. The Jove of power make me, most weak, most weak, Your reconciler! Wars 'twixt you twain would be As if the world should cleave, and that slain men Should solder up the rift.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: When it appears to you where this begins, Turn your displeasure that way, for our faults Can never be so equal that your love Can equally move with them. Provide your going; Choose your own company, and command what cost Your heart has mind to.

scenes.location: Athens. Another Room in Antony's House.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: How now, friend Eros?

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: There's strange news come, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: What, man?

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Caesar and Lepidus have made wars upon Pompey.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: This is old. What is the success?

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Caesar, having made use of him in the wars 'gainst Pompey, presently denied him rivality; would not let him partake in the glory of the action, and, not resting here, accuses him of letters he had formerly wrote to Pompey; upon his own appeal, seizes him. So the poor third is up, till death enlarge his confine.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Then, world, thou hast a pair of chaps, no more, And throw between them all the food thou hast, They'll grind the one the other. Where's Antony?

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: He's walking in the garden, thus, and spurns The rush that lies before him; cries "Fool Lepidus!" And threats the throat of that his officer That murdered Pompey.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Our great navy's rigged.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: For Italy and Caesar. More, Domitius: My lord desires you presently. My news I might have told hereafter.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: 'Twill be naught, But let it be. Bring me to Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Come, sir.

scenes.location: Rome. A Room in Caesar's House.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Contemning Rome, he has done all this, and more In Alexandria. Here's the manner of 't: I' th' market-place, on a tribunal silvered, Cleopatra and himself in chairs of gold Were publicly enthroned. At the feet sat Caesarion, whom they call my father's son, And all the unlawful issue that their lust Since then hath made between them. Unto her He gave the stablishment of Egypt; made her Of lower Syria, Cyprus, Lydia, Absolute queen.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: This in the public eye?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I' th' common showplace where they exercise. His sons he there proclaimed the kings of kings: Great Media, Parthia, and Armenia He gave to Alexander; to Ptolemy he assigned Syria, Cilicia, and Phoenicia. She In th' habiliments of the goddess Isis That day appeared, and oft before gave audience, As 'tis reported, so.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: Let Rome be thus informed.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Who, queasy with his insolence already, Will their good thoughts call from him.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: The people knows it and have now received His accusations.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Who does he accuse?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Caesar, and that, having in Sicily Sextus Pompeius spoiled, we had not rated him His part o' th' isle. Then does he say he lent me Some shipping, unrestored. Lastly, he frets That Lepidus of the triumvirate Should be deposed and, being, that we detain All his revenue.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Sir, this should be answered.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: 'Tis done already, and messenger gone. I have told him Lepidus was grown too cruel, That he his high authority abused, And did deserve his change. For what I have conquered I grant him part; but then in his Armenia And other of his conquered kingdoms, I Demand the like.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: He'll never yield to that.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Nor must not then be yielded to in this.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: Hail, Caesar, and my lord! Hail, most dear Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: That ever I should call thee castaway!

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: You have not called me so, nor have you cause.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Why have you stolen upon us thus? You come not Like Caesar's sister. The wife of Antony Should have an army for an usher, and The neighs of horse to tell of her approach Long ere she did appear. The trees by th' way Should have borne men, and expectation fainted, Longing for what it had not. Nay, the dust Should have ascended to the roof of heaven, Raised by your populous troops. But you are come A market-maid to Rome, and have prevented The ostentation of our love, which, left unshown, Is often left unloved. We should have met you By sea and land, supplying every stage With an augmented greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: Good my lord, To come thus was I not constrained, but did it On my free will. My lord, Mark Antony, Hearing that you prepared for war, acquainted My grieved ear withal, whereon I begged His pardon for return.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Which soon he granted, Being an abstract 'tween his lust and him.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: Do not say so, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: I have eyes upon him, And his affairs come to me on the wind. Where is he now?

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: My lord, in Athens.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: No, my most wronged sister. Cleopatra Hath nodded him to her. He hath given his empire Up to a whore, who now are levying The kings o' th' earth for war. He hath assembled Bocchus, the king of Libya; Archelaus Of Cappadocia; Philadelphos, king Of Paphlagonia; the Thracian king, Adallas; King Manchus of Arabia; King of Pont; Herod of Jewry; Mithridates, king Of Comagene; Polemon and Amyntas, The kings of Mede and Lycaonia, With a more larger list of sceptres.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: Ay me, most wretched, That have my heart parted betwixt two friends That does afflict each other!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Welcome hither. Your letters did withhold our breaking forth Till we perceived both how you were wrong led And we in negligent danger. Cheer your heart. Be you not troubled with the time, which drives O'er your content these strong necessities, But let determined things to destiny Hold unbewailed their way. Welcome to Rome, Nothing more dear to me. You are abused Beyond the mark of thought, and the high gods, To do you justice, make their ministers Of us and those that love you. Best of comfort, And ever welcome to us.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Welcome, lady.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: Welcome, dear madam. Each heart in Rome does love and pity you. Only th' adulterous Antony, most large In his abominations, turns you off And gives his potent regiment to a trull That noises it against us.

dialogues.speaker: Octavia
dialogues.line: Is it so, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Most certain. Sister, welcome. Pray you Be ever known to patience. My dear'st sister!

scenes.location: Antony's Camp near the Promontory of Actium.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I will be even with thee, doubt it not.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: But why, why, why?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Thou hast forspoke my being in these wars And say'st it is not fit.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Well, is it, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Is 't not denounced against us? Why should not we Be there in person?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Well, I could reply: If we should serve with horse and mares together, The horse were merely lost. The mares would bear A soldier and his horse.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What is't you say?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Your presence needs must puzzle Antony, Take from his heart, take from his brain, from 's time, What should not then be spared. He is already Traduced for levity, and 'tis said in Rome That Photinus, an eunuch, and your maids Manage this war.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Sink Rome, and their tongues rot That speak against us! A charge we bear i' th' war, And, as the president of my kingdom, will Appear there for a man. Speak not against it. I will not stay behind.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Nay, I have done. Here comes the Emperor.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Is it not strange, Canidius, That from Tarentum and Brundusium He could so quickly cut the Ionian sea And take in Toryne?-You have heard on 't, sweet?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Celerity is never more admired Than by the negligent.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: A good rebuke, Which might have well becomed the best of men To taunt at slackness.-Canidius, we Will fight with him by sea.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: By sea, what else?

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: Why will my lord do so?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: For that he dares us to 't.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: So hath my lord dared him to single fight.

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: Ay, and to wage this battle at Pharsalia, Where Caesar fought with Pompey. But these offers, Which serve not for his vantage, he shakes off, And so should you.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Your ships are not well manned, Your mariners are muleteers, reapers, people Engrossed by swift impress. In Caesar's fleet Are those that often have 'gainst Pompey fought. Their ships are yare, yours heavy. No disgrace Shall fall you for refusing him at sea, Being prepared for land.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: By sea, by sea.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Most worthy sir, you therein throw away The absolute soldiership you have by land; Distract your army, which doth most consist Of war-marked footmen; leave unexecuted Your own renowned knowledge; quite forgo The way which promises assurance; and Give up yourself merely to chance and hazard From firm security.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I'll fight at sea.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I have sixty sails, Caesar none better.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Our overplus of shipping will we burn, And with the rest full-manned, from th' head of Actium Beat th' approaching Caesar. But if we fail, We then can do 't at land. Thy business?

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The news is true, my lord; he is descried. Caesar has taken Toryne.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Can he be there in person? 'Tis impossible; Strange that his power should be. Canidius, Our nineteen legions thou shalt hold by land, And our twelve thousand horse. We'll to our ship. Away, my Thetis! How now, worthy soldier?

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: O noble emperor, do not fight by sea. Trust not to rotten planks. Do you misdoubt This sword and these my wounds? Let th' Egyptians And the Phoenicians go a-ducking. We Have used to conquer standing on the earth And fighting foot to foot.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Well, well, away.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: By Hercules, I think I am i' th' right.

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: Soldier, thou art. But his whole action grows Not in the power on 't. So our leader's led, And we are women's men.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: You keep by land The legions and the horse whole, do you not?

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: Marcus Octavius, Marcus Justeius, Publicola, and Caelius are for sea, But we keep whole by land. This speed of Caesar's Carries beyond belief.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: While he was yet in Rome, His power went out in such distractions as Beguiled all spies.

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: Who's his lieutenant, hear you?

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: They say one Taurus.

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: Well I know the man.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: The Emperor calls Canidius.

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: With news the time's with labour, and throes forth Each minute some.

scenes.location: A plain near Actium.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Taurus!

dialogues.speaker: Taurus
dialogues.line: My lord?

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Strike not by land; keep whole; provoke not battle Till we have done at sea. Do not exceed The prescript of this scroll. Our fortune lies Upon this jump.

scenes.location: Another part of the Plain.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Set we our squadrons on yon side o' th' hill In eye of Caesar's battle, from which place We may the number of the ships behold And so proceed accordingly.

scenes.location: Another part of the Plain.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Naught, naught, all naught! I can behold no longer. Th' Antoniad, the Egyptian admiral, With all their sixty, fly and turn the rudder. To see 't mine eyes are blasted.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: Gods and goddesses, All the whole synod of them!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: What's thy passion?

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: The greater cantle of the world is lost With very ignorance. We have kissed away Kingdoms and provinces.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: How appears the fight?

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: On our side, like the tokened pestilence, Where death is sure. Yon ribaudred nag of Egypt, Whom leprosy o'ertake, i' th' midst o' th' fight, When vantage like a pair of twins appeared, Both as the same-or, rather, ours the elder- The breeze upon her, like a cow in June, Hoists sails and flies.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: That I beheld. Mine eyes did sicken at the sight and could not Endure a further view.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: She once being loofed, The noble ruin of her magic, Antony, Claps on his sea-wing and, like a doting mallard, Leaving the fight in height, flies after her. I never saw an action of such shame. Experience, manhood, honour, ne'er before Did violate so itself.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Alack, alack!

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: Our fortune on the sea is out of breath And sinks most lamentably. Had our general Been what he knew himself, it had gone well. O, he has given example for our flight Most grossly by his own!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Ay, are you thereabouts? Why, then, good night indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: Toward Peloponnesus are they fled.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: 'Tis easy to't, and there I will attend What further comes.

dialogues.speaker: Canidius
dialogues.line: To Caesar will I render My legions and my horse. Six kings already Show me the way of yielding.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I'll yet follow The wounded chance of Antony, though my reason Sits in the wind against me.

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Hark, the land bids me tread no more upon't. It is ashamed to bear me. Friends, come hither. I am so lated in the world that I Have lost my way for ever. I have a ship Laden with gold. Take that, divide it. Fly, And make your peace with Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Fly? Not we.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I have fled myself, and have instructed cowards To run and show their shoulders. Friends, be gone. I have myself resolved upon a course Which has no need of you. Be gone. My treasure's in the harbour. Take it. O, I followed that I blush to look upon. My very hairs do mutiny, for the white Reprove the brown for rashness, and they them For fear and doting. Friends, be gone. You shall Have letters from me to some friends that will Sweep your way for you. Pray you, look not sad, Nor make replies of loathness. Take the hint Which my despair proclaims. Let that be left Which leaves itself. To the sea-side straightway. I will possess you of that ship and treasure. Leave me, I pray, a little-pray you, now, Nay, do so; for indeed I have lost command. Therefore I pray you. I'll see you by and by.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Nay, gentle madam, to him! Comfort him.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Do, most dear queen.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Do! Why, what else?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Let me sit down. O Juno!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: No, no, no, no, no.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: See you here, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: O, fie, fie, fie!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Madam.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Madam, O good empress!

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Sir, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Yes, my lord, yes. He at Philippi kept His sword e'en like a dancer, while I struck The lean and wrinkled Cassius, and 'twas I That the mad Brutus ended. He alone Dealt on lieutenantry, and no practice had In the brave squares of war. Yet now-no matter.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Ah, stand by.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: The Queen, my lord, the Queen!

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Go to him, madam; speak to him. He is unqualitied with very shame.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Well then, sustain me. O!

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Most noble sir, arise. The Queen approaches. Her head's declined, and death will seize her but Your comfort makes the rescue.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I have offended reputation, A most unnoble swerving.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Sir, the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: O, whither hast thou led me, Egypt? See How I convey my shame out of thine eyes By looking back what I have left behind 'Stroyed in dishonour.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O my lord, my lord, Forgive my fearful sails! I little thought You would have followed.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Egypt, thou knew'st too well My heart was to thy rudder tied by th' strings, And thou shouldst tow me after. O'er my spirit Thy full supremacy thou knew'st, and that Thy beck might from the bidding of the gods Command me.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O, my pardon!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Now I must To the young man send humble treaties, dodge And palter in the shifts of lowness, who With half the bulk o' th' world played as I pleased, Making and marring fortunes. You did know How much you were my conqueror, and that My sword, made weak by my affection, would Obey it on all cause.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Pardon, pardon!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Fall not a tear, I say; one of them rates All that is won and lost. Give me a kiss. Even this repays me. We sent our schoolmaster. Is he come back? Love, I am full of lead. Some wine Within there, and our viands! Fortune knows We scorn her most when most she offers blows.

scenes.location: Caesar's camp in Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Let him appear that's come from Antony. Know you him?

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Caesar, 'tis his schoolmaster- An argument that he is plucked, when hither He sends so poor a pinion of his wing, Which had superfluous kings for messengers Not many moons gone by.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Approach, and speak.

dialogues.speaker: Ambassador
dialogues.line: Such as I am, I come from Antony. I was of late as petty to his ends As is the morn-dew on the myrtle leaf To his grand sea.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Be't so. Declare thine office.

dialogues.speaker: Ambassador
dialogues.line: Lord of his fortunes he salutes thee, and Requires to live in Egypt, which not granted, He lessens his requests, and to thee sues To let him breathe between the heavens and earth, A private man in Athens. This for him. Next, Cleopatra does confess thy greatness, Submits her to thy might, and of thee craves The circle of the Ptolemies for her heirs, Now hazarded to thy grace.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: For Antony, I have no ears to his request. The queen Of audience nor desire shall fail, so she From Egypt drive her all-disgraced friend, Or take his life there. This if she perform, She shall not sue unheard. So to them both.

dialogues.speaker: Ambassador
dialogues.line: Fortune pursue thee!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Bring him through the bands.  To try thy eloquence now 'tis time. Dispatch. From Antony win Cleopatra. Promise, And in our name, what she requires; add more, From thine invention, offers. Women are not In their best fortunes strong, but want will perjure The ne'er-touch'd vestal. Try thy cunning, Thidias; Make thine own edict for thy pains, which we Will answer as a law.

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: Caesar, I go.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Observe how Antony becomes his flaw, And what thou think'st his very action speaks In every power that moves.

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: Caesar, I shall.

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What shall we do, Enobarbus?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Think, and die.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Is Antony or we in fault for this?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Antony only, that would make his will Lord of his reason. What though you fled From that great face of war, whose several ranges Frighted each other? Why should he follow? The itch of his affection should not then Have nicked his captainship, at such a point, When half to half the world opposed, he being The mered question. 'Twas a shame no less Than was his loss, to course your flying flags And leave his navy gazing.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Prithee, peace.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Is that his answer?

dialogues.speaker: Ambassador
dialogues.line: Ay, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: The Queen shall then have courtesy, so she Will yield us up.

dialogues.speaker: Ambassador
dialogues.line: He says so.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Let her know't.- To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head, And he will fill thy wishes to the brim With principalities.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: That head, my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: To him again. Tell him he wears the rose Of youth upon him, from which the world should note Something particular: his coin, ships, legions, May be a coward's; whose ministers would prevail Under the service of a child as soon As i' th' command of Caesar. I dare him therefore To lay his gay comparisons apart, And answer me declined, sword against sword, Ourselves alone. I'll write it. Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Yes, like enough high-battled Caesar will Unstate his happiness, and be staged to th' show Against a sworder! I see men's judgments are A parcel of their fortunes, and things outward Do draw the inward quality after them To suffer all alike. That he should dream, Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdued His judgment too.

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: A messenger from Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What, no more ceremony? See, my women, Against the blown rose may they stop their nose That kneeled unto the buds. Admit him, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Mine honesty and I begin to square. The loyalty well held to fools does make Our faith mere folly. Yet he that can endure To follow with allegiance a fallen lord Does conquer him that did his master conquer, And earns a place i' th' story.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Caesar's will?

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: Hear it apart.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: None but friends. Say boldly.

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: So haply are they friends to Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has, Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master Will leap to be his friend. For us, you know Whose he is we are, and that is Caesar's.

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: So.- Thus then, thou most renowned: Caesar entreats Not to consider in what case thou stand'st Further than he is Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Go on; right royal.

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: He knows that you embrace not Antony As you did love, but as you feared him.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O!

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: The scars upon your honour, therefore, he Does pity as constrained blemishes, Not as deserved.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: He is a god and knows What is most right. Mine honour was not yielded, But conquered merely.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: To be sure of that, I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for Thy dearest quit thee.

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: Shall I say to Caesar What you require of him? For he partly begs To be desired to give. It much would please him That of his fortunes you should make a staff To lean upon. But it would warm his spirits To hear from me you had left Antony, And put yourself under his shroud, The universal landlord.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: My name is Thidias.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Most kind messenger, Say to great Caesar this in deputation: I kiss his conqu'ring hand. Tell him I am prompt To lay my crown at's feet, and there to kneel. Tell him, from his all-obeying breath I hear The doom of Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: 'Tis your noblest course. Wisdom and fortune combating together, If that the former dare but what it can, No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay My duty on your hand.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Your Caesar's father oft, When he hath mused of taking kingdoms in, Bestowed his lips on that unworthy place As it rained kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Favours, by Jove that thunders! What art thou, fellow?

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: One that but performs The bidding of the fullest man and worthiest To have command obeyed.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: You will be whipped.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Approach there.-Ah, you kite!-Now, gods and devils, Authority melts from me. Of late when I cried "Ho!" Like boys unto a muss, kings would start forth And cry "Your will?" Have you no ears? I am Antony yet. Take hence this jack and whip him.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: 'Tis better playing with a lion's whelp Than with an old one dying.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Moon and stars! Whip him. Were't twenty of the greatest tributaries That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them So saucy with the hand of she here-what's her name Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him, fellows, Till like a boy you see him cringe his face And whine aloud for mercy. Take him hence.

dialogues.speaker: Thidias
dialogues.line: Mark Antony-

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Tug him away. Being whipp'd, Bring him again. This jack of Caesar's shall Bear us an errand to him. You were half blasted ere I knew you. Ha! Have I my pillow left unpressed in Rome, Forborne the getting of a lawful race, And by a gem of women, to be abused By one that looks on feeders?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Good my lord-

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: You have been a boggler ever. But when we in our viciousness grow hard- O misery on't!-the wise gods seal our eyes, In our own filth drop our clear judgments, make us Adore our errors, laugh at's while we strut To our confusion.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O, is't come to this?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I found you as a morsel cold upon Dead Caesar's trencher; nay, you were a fragment Of Gneius Pompey's, besides what hotter hours, Unregistered in vulgar fame, you have Luxuriously pick'd out. For I am sure, Though you can guess what temperance should be, You know not what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Wherefore is this?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: To let a fellow that will take rewards And say "God quit you!" be familiar with My playfellow, your hand, this kingly seal And plighter of high hearts! O that I were Upon the hill of Basan, to outroar The horned herd! For I have savage cause, And to proclaim it civilly were like A haltered neck which does the hangman thank For being yare about him. Is he whipped?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: Soundly, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Cried he? And begged he pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Servant
dialogues.line: He did ask favour.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: If that thy father live, let him repent Thou wast not made his daughter; and be thou sorry To follow Caesar in his triumph, since Thou hast been whipped for following him. Henceforth The white hand of a lady fever thee; Shake thou to look on't. Get thee back to Caesar; Tell him thy entertainment. Look thou say He makes me angry with him; for he seems Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am, Not what he knew I was. He makes me angry, And at this time most easy 'tis to do't, When my good stars that were my former guides Have empty left their orbs and shot their fires Into th' abysm of hell. If he mislike My speech and what is done, tell him he has Hipparchus, my enfranched bondman, whom He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture, As he shall like, to quit me. Urge it thou. Hence with thy stripes, be gone.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Have you done yet?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Alack, our terrene moon is now eclipsed, And it portends alone the fall of Antony.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I must stay his time.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes With one that ties his points?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Not know me yet?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Cold-hearted toward me?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Ah, dear, if I be so, From my cold heart let heaven engender hail And poison it in the source, and the first stone Drop in my neck; as it determines, so Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite, Till, by degrees the memory of my womb, Together with my brave Egyptians all, By the discandying of this pelleted storm, Lie graveless, till the flies and gnats of Nile Have buried them for prey!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I am satisfied. Caesar sits down in Alexandria, where I will oppose his fate. Our force by land Hath nobly held; our severed navy too Have knit again, and fleet, threat'ning most sea-like. Where hast thou been, my heart? Dost thou hear, lady? If from the field I shall return once more To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood. I and my sword will earn our chronicle. There's hope in't yet.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: That's my brave lord!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I will be treble-sinewed, hearted, breathed, And fight maliciously. For when mine hours Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives Of me for jests. But now I'll set my teeth And send to darkness all that stop me. Come, Let's have one other gaudy night. Call to me All my sad captains. Fill our bowls once more Let's mock the midnight bell.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: It is my birthday. I had thought t'have held it poor, but since my lord Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: We will yet do well.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Call all his noble captains to my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Do so; we'll speak to them; and tonight I'll force The wine peep through their scars. Come on, my queen, There's sap in't yet. The next time I do fight I'll make Death love me, for I will contend Even with his pestilent scythe.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Now he'll outstare the lightning. To be furious Is to be frighted out of fear, and in that mood The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still A diminution in our captain's brain Restores his heart. When valour preys on reason, It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek Some way to leave him.

scenes.location: Caesar's Camp at Alexandria.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: He calls me boy, and chides as he had power To beat me out of Egypt. My messenger He hath whipped with rods; dares me to personal combat, Caesar to Antony. Let the old ruffian know I have many other ways to die; meantime Laugh at his challenge.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: Caesar must think, When one so great begins to rage, he's hunted Even to falling. Give him no breath, but now Make boot of his distraction. Never anger Made good guard for itself.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Let our best heads Know that tomorrow the last of many battles We mean to fight. Within our files there are, Of those that served Mark Antony but late, Enough to fetch him in. See it done, And feast the army; we have store to do't, And they have earned the waste. Poor Antony!

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: He will not fight with me, Domitius?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Why should he not?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: He thinks, being twenty times of better fortune, He is twenty men to one.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Tomorrow, soldier, By sea and land I'll fight. Or I will live, Or bathe my dying honour in the blood Shall make it live again. Woo't thou fight well?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I'll strike, and cry "Take all."

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Well said. Come on. Call forth my household servants. Let's tonight Be bounteous at our meal.- Give me thy hand. Thou has been rightly honest; so hast thou, Thou, and thou, and thou. You have served me well, And kings have been your fellows.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What means this?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: 'Tis one of those odd tricks which sorrow shoots Out of the mind.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: And thou art honest too. I wish I could be made so many men, And all of you clapped up together in An Antony, that I might do you service So good as you have done.

dialogues.speaker: All The Servants
dialogues.line: The gods forbid!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Well, my good fellows, wait on me tonight. Scant not my cups, and make as much of me As when mine empire was your fellow too And suffered my command.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What does he mean?

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: To make his followers weep.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Tend me tonight; May be it is the period of your duty. Haply you shall not see me more, or if, A mangled shadow. Perchance tomorrow You'll serve another master. I look on you As one that takes his leave. Mine honest friends, I turn you not away, but, like a master Married to your good service, stay till death. Tend me tonight two hours, I ask no more, And the gods yield you for't!

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: What mean you, sir, To give them this discomfort? Look, they weep, And I, an ass, am onion-eyed. For shame, Transform us not to women.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Ho, ho, ho! Now the witch take me if I meant it thus! Grace grow where those drops fall! My hearty friends, You take me in too dolorous a sense, For I spake to you for your comfort, did desire you To burn this night with torches. Know, my hearts, I hope well of tomorrow, and will lead you Where rather I'll expect victorious life Than death and honour. Let's to supper, come, And drown consideration.

scenes.location: Alexandria. Before the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Brother, good night. Tomorrow is the day.

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: It will determine one way. Fare you well. Heard you of nothing strange about the streets?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Nothing. What news?

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Belike 'tis but a rumour. Good night to you.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Well, sir, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Soldiers, have careful watch.

dialogues.speaker: Third Soldier
dialogues.line: And you. Good night, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Here we. And if tomorrow Our navy thrive, I have an absolute hope Our landmen will stand up.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: 'Tis a brave army, and full of purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Peace, what noise?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: List, list!

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: Hark!

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Music i' th' air.

dialogues.speaker: Third Soldier
dialogues.line: Under the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Fourth Soldier
dialogues.line: It signs well, does it not?

dialogues.speaker: Third Soldier
dialogues.line: No.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Peace, I say! What should this mean?

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: 'Tis the god Hercules, whom Antony loved, Now leaves him.

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Walk. Let's see if other watchmen Do hear what we do.

dialogues.speaker: Second Soldier
dialogues.line: How now, masters!

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: How now! How now! Do you hear this?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Ay. Is't not strange?

dialogues.speaker: Third Soldier
dialogues.line: Do you hear, masters? Do you hear?

dialogues.speaker: First Soldier
dialogues.line: Follow the noise so far as we have quarter. Let's see how it will give off.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Content. 'Tis strange.

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Eros! Mine armour, Eros!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Sleep a little.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: No, my chuck.-Eros! Come, mine armour, Eros! Come, good fellow, put thine iron on. If fortune be not ours today, it is Because we brave her. Come.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Nay, I'll help too. What's this for?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Ah, let be, let be! Thou art The armourer of my heart. False, false. This, this!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Sooth, la, I'll help. Thus it must be.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Well, well, We shall thrive now. Seest thou, my good fellow? Go put on thy defences.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Briefly, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Is not this buckled well?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Rarely, rarely. He that unbuckles this, till we do please To daff't for our repose, shall hear a storm. Thou fumblest, Eros, and my queen's a squire More tight at this than thou. Dispatch. O love, That thou couldst see my wars today, and knew'st The royal occupation, thou shouldst see A workman in't. Good morrow to thee. Welcome. Thou look'st like him that knows a warlike charge. To business that we love we rise betime And go to't with delight.

dialogues.speaker: Officer
dialogues.line: A thousand, sir, Early though't be, have on their riveted trim And at the port expect you.

dialogues.speaker: Captain
dialogues.line: The morn is fair. Good morrow, general.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Good morrow, general.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: 'Tis well blown, lads. This morning, like the spirit of a youth That means to be of note, begins betimes. So, so. Come, give me that. This way. Well said. Fare thee well, dame. Whate'er becomes of me, This is a soldier's kiss.  Rebukeable And worthy shameful check it were, to stand On more mechanic compliment. I'll leave thee Now like a man of steel.-You that will fight, Follow me close, I'll bring you to't. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Please you, retire to your chamber.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Lead me. He goes forth gallantly. That he and Caesar might Determine this great war in single fight! Then Antony-but now-. Well, on.

scenes.location: Antony's camp near Alexandria.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: The gods make this a happy day to Antony!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Would thou and those thy scars had once prevailed To make me fight at land!

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: Hadst thou done so, The kings that have revolted and the soldier That has this morning left thee would have still Followed thy heels.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Who's gone this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: Who? One ever near thee. Call for Enobarbus, He shall not hear thee, or from Caesar's camp Say "I am none of thine."

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: What sayest thou?

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: Sir, He is with Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Sir, his chests and treasure He has not with him.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Is he gone?

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: Most certain.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Go, Eros, send his treasure after. Do it. Detain no jot, I charge thee. Write to him- I will subscribe-gentle adieus and greetings. Say that I wish he never find more cause To change a master. O, my fortunes have Corrupted honest men! Dispatch.-Enobarbus!

scenes.location: Alexandria. Caesar's camp.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Go forth, Agrippa, and begin the fight. Our will is Antony be took alive; Make it so known.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Caesar, I shall.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: The time of universal peace is near. Prove this a prosp'rous day, the three-nooked world Shall bear the olive freely.

dialogues.speaker: Messenger
dialogues.line: Antony Is come into the field.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Go charge Agrippa Plant those that have revolted in the van That Antony may seem to spend his fury Upon himself.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Alexas did revolt and went to Jewry on Affairs of Antony; there did dissuade Great Herod to incline himself to Caesar And leave his master Antony. For this pains Caesar hath hanged him. Canidius and the rest That fell away have entertainment but No honourable trust. I have done ill, Of which I do accuse myself so sorely That I will joy no more. Enter a Soldier of Caesar's.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: Enobarbus, Antony Hath after thee sent all thy treasure, with His bounty overplus. The messenger Came on my guard, and at thy tent is now Unloading of his mules.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I give it you.

dialogues.speaker: Soldier
dialogues.line: Mock not, Enobarbus. I tell you true. Best you safed the bringer Out of the host. I must attend mine office, Or would have done't myself. Your emperor Continues still a Jove.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: I am alone the villain of the earth, And feel I am so most. O Antony, Thou mine of bounty, how wouldst thou have paid My better service, when my turpitude Thou dost so crown with gold! This blows my heart. If swift thought break it not, a swifter mean Shall outstrike thought, but thought will do't, I feel. I fight against thee! No, I will go seek Some ditch wherein to die; the foul'st best fits My latter part of life.

scenes.location: Field of battle between the Camps.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: Retire! We have engaged ourselves too far. Caesar himself has work, and our oppression Exceeds what we expected. Alarums. Enter Antony and Scarus wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: O my brave emperor, this is fought indeed! Had we done so at first, we had droven them home With clouts about their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Thou bleed'st apace.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: I had a wound here that was like a T, But now 'tis made an H. _Sounds retreat far off._

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: They do retire.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: We'll beat 'em into bench-holes. I have yet Room for six scotches more.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: They are beaten, sir, and our advantage serves For a fair victory.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: Let us score their backs And snatch 'em up as we take hares, behind. 'Tis sport to maul a runner.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I will reward thee Once for thy sprightly comfort, and tenfold For thy good valour. Come thee on.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: I'll halt after.

scenes.location: Under the Walls of Alexandria.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: We have beat him to his camp. Run one before And let the Queen know of our gests. Tomorrow, Before the sun shall see's, we'll spill the blood That has today escaped. I thank you all, For doughty-handed are you, and have fought Not as you served the cause, but as't had been Each man's like mine. You have shown all Hectors. Tell them your feats; whilst they with joyful tears Wash the congealment from your wounds and kiss The honoured gashes whole.  Give me thy hand. To this great fairy I'll commend thy acts, Make her thanks bless thee. O thou day o' th' world, Chain mine armed neck. Leap thou, attire and all, Through proof of harness to my heart, and there Ride on the pants triumphing.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Lord of lords! O infinite virtue, com'st thou smiling from The world's great snare uncaught?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Mine nightingale, We have beat them to their beds. What, girl! Though grey Do something mingle with our younger brown, yet ha' we A brain that nourishes our nerves and can Get goal for goal of youth. Behold this man. Commend unto his lips thy favouring hand.- Kiss it, my warrior. He hath fought today As if a god, in hate of mankind, had Destroyed in such a shape.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I'll give thee, friend, An armour all of gold. It was a king's.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: He has deserved it, were it carbuncled Like holy Phœbus' car. Give me thy hand. Through Alexandria make a jolly march; Bear our hacked targets like the men that owe them. Had our great palace the capacity To camp this host, we all would sup together And drink carouses to the next day's fate, Which promises royal peril.-Trumpeters, With brazen din blast you the city's ear; Make mingle with our rattling tabourines, That heaven and earth may strike their sounds together, Applauding our approach.

scenes.location: Caesar's camp.

dialogues.speaker: Sentry
dialogues.line: If we be not relieved within this hour, We must return to th' court of guard. The night Is shiny, and they say we shall embattle By th' second hour i' th' morn.

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: This last day was a shrewd one to's.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: O, bear me witness, night.-

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: What man is this?

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: Stand close and list him.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: Be witness to me, O thou blessed moon, When men revolted shall upon record Bear hateful memory, poor Enobarbus did Before thy face repent.

dialogues.speaker: Sentry
dialogues.line: Enobarbus?

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Peace! Hark further.

dialogues.speaker: Enobarbus
dialogues.line: O sovereign mistress of true melancholy, The poisonous damp of night disponge upon me, That life, a very rebel to my will, May hang no longer on me. Throw my heart Against the flint and hardness of my fault, Which, being dried with grief, will break to powder And finish all foul thoughts. O Antony, Nobler than my revolt is infamous, Forgive me in thine own particular, But let the world rank me in register A master-leaver and a fugitive. O Antony! O Antony!

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: Let's speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: Sentry
dialogues.line: Let's hear him, for the things he speaks may concern Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Let's do so. But he sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Sentry
dialogues.line: Swoons rather, for so bad a prayer as his Was never yet for sleep.

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: Go we to him.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Awake, sir, awake! Speak to us.

dialogues.speaker: First Watch
dialogues.line: Hear you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Sentry
dialogues.line: The hand of death hath raught him. Hark! The drums Demurely wake the sleepers. Let us bear him To th' court of guard; he is of note. Our hour Is fully out.

dialogues.speaker: Second Watch
dialogues.line: Come on, then. He may recover yet.

scenes.location: Ground between the two Camps.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Their preparation is today by sea; We please them not by land.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: For both, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I would they'd fight i' th' fire or i' th' air; We'd fight there too. But this it is: our foot Upon the hills adjoining to the city Shall stay with us-order for sea is given; They have put forth the haven- Where their appointment we may best discover And look on their endeavour.

scenes.location: Another part of the Ground.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: But being charged, we will be still by land, Which, as I take't, we shall, for his best force Is forth to man his galleys. To the vales, And hold our best advantage.

scenes.location: Another part of the Ground.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Yet they are not joined. Where yond pine does stand I shall discover all. I'll bring thee word Straight how 'tis like to go.

dialogues.speaker: Scarus
dialogues.line: Swallows have built In Cleopatra's sails their nests. The augurs Say they know not, they cannot tell; look grimly, And dare not speak their knowledge. Antony Is valiant and dejected, and by starts His fretted fortunes give him hope and fear Of what he has and has not.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: All is lost! This foul Egyptian hath betrayed me. My fleet hath yielded to the foe, and yonder They cast their caps up and carouse together Like friends long lost. Triple-turned whore! 'Tis thou Hast sold me to this novice, and my heart Makes only wars on thee. Bid them all fly; For when I am revenged upon my charm, I have done all. Bid them all fly! Be gone! O sun, thy uprise shall I see no more. Fortune and Antony part here; even here Do we shake hands. All come to this! The hearts That spanieled me at heels, to whom I gave Their wishes, do discandy, melt their sweets On blossoming Caesar, and this pine is barked That overtopped them all. Betray'd I am: O this false soul of Egypt! This grave charm, Whose eye becked forth my wars and called them home, Whose bosom was my crownet, my chief end, Like a right gypsy hath at fast and loose Beguiled me to the very heart of loss. What, Eros, Eros! Ah, thou spell! Avaunt!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Why is my lord enraged against his love?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Vanish, or I shall give thee thy deserving And blemish Caesar's triumph. Let him take thee And hoist thee up to the shouting plebeians! Follow his chariot, like the greatest spot Of all thy sex; most monster-like be shown For poor'st diminutives, for dolts, and let Patient Octavia plough thy visage up With her prepared nails. 'Tis well thou'rt gone, If it be well to live; but better 'twere Thou fell'st into my fury, for one death Might have prevented many.-Eros, ho!- The shirt of Nessus is upon me. Teach me, Alcides, thou mine ancestor, thy rage. Let me lodge Lichas on the horns o' th' moon, And with those hands that grasped the heaviest club Subdue my worthiest self. The witch shall die. To the young Roman boy she hath sold me, and I fall Under this plot. She dies for't.-Eros, ho!

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Palace.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Help me, my women! O, he is more mad Than Telamon for his shield; the boar of Thessaly Was never so embossed.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: To th' monument! There lock yourself and send him word you are dead. The soul and body rive not more in parting Than greatness going off.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: To th' monument! Mardian, go tell him I have slain myself. Say that the last I spoke was "Antony", And word it, prithee, piteously. Hence, Mardian, And bring me how he takes my death.-To th' monument!

scenes.location: Alexandria. Another Room.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Eros, thou yet behold'st me?

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Ay, noble lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Sometime we see a cloud that's dragonish, A vapour sometime like a bear or lion, A towered citadel, a pendant rock, A forked mountain, or blue promontory With trees upon't, that nod unto the world And mock our eyes with air. Thou hast seen these signs. They are black vesper's pageants.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Ay, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: That which is now a horse, even with a thought The rack dislimns and makes it indistinct As water is in water.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: It does, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: My good knave Eros, now thy captain is Even such a body. Here I am Antony, Yet cannot hold this visible shape, my knave. I made these wars for Egypt, and the Queen, Whose heart I thought I had, for she had mine, Which, whilst it was mine, had annexed unto't A million more, now lost-she, Eros, has Packed cards with Caesar, and false-played my glory Unto an enemy's triumph. Nay, weep not, gentle Eros. There is left us Ourselves to end ourselves. O, thy vile lady! She has robbed me of my sword.

dialogues.speaker: Mardian
dialogues.line: No, Antony, My mistress loved thee and her fortunes mingled With thine entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Hence, saucy eunuch! Peace! She hath betrayed me and shall die the death.

dialogues.speaker: Mardian
dialogues.line: Death of one person can be paid but once, And that she has discharged. What thou wouldst do Is done unto thy hand. The last she spake Was "Antony! Most noble Antony!" Then in the midst a tearing groan did break The name of Antony; it was divided Between her heart and lips. She rendered life, Thy name so buried in her.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Dead, then?

dialogues.speaker: Mardian
dialogues.line: Dead.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Unarm, Eros. The long day's task is done, And we must sleep.-That thou depart'st hence safe Does pay thy labour richly. Go. Off, pluck off! The sevenfold shield of Ajax cannot keep The battery from my heart. O, cleave, my sides! Heart, once be stronger than thy continent; Crack thy frail case! Apace, Eros, apace! No more a soldier. Bruised pieces, go; You have been nobly borne. From me awhile. I will o'ertake thee, Cleopatra, and Weep for my pardon. So it must be, for now All length is torture. Since the torch is out, Lie down, and stray no farther. Now all labour Mars what it does; yea, very force entangles Itself with strength. Seal then, and all is done. Eros!-I come, my queen.-Eros!-Stay for me. Where souls do couch on flowers, we'll hand in hand, And with our sprightly port make the ghosts gaze. Dido and her Aeneas shall want troops, And all the haunt be ours.-Come, Eros, Eros!

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: What would my lord?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Since Cleopatra died, I have lived in such dishonour that the gods Detest my baseness. I, that with my sword Quartered the world, and o'er green Neptune's back With ships made cities, condemn myself to lack The courage of a woman; less noble mind Than she which, by her death, our Caesar tells "I am conqueror of myself." Thou art sworn, Eros, That when the exigent should come, which now Is come indeed, when I should see behind me Th' inevitable prosecution of Disgrace and horror, that on my command Thou then wouldst kill me. Do't. The time is come. Thou strik'st not me; 'tis Caesar thou defeat'st. Put colour in thy cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: The gods withhold me! Shall I do that which all the Parthian darts, Though enemy, lost aim and could not?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Eros, Wouldst thou be windowed in great Rome and see Thy master thus with pleached arms, bending down His corrigible neck, his face subdued To penetrative shame, whilst the wheeled seat Of fortunate Caesar, drawn before him, branded His baseness that ensued?

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: I would not see't.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Come, then, for with a wound I must be cured. Draw that thy honest sword, which thou hast worn Most useful for thy country.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: O, sir, pardon me!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: When I did make thee free, swor'st thou not then To do this when I bade thee? Do it at once, Or thy precedent services are all But accidents unpurposed. Draw, and come.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Turn from me then that noble countenance Wherein the worship of the whole world lies.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Lo thee!

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: My sword is drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Then let it do at once The thing why thou hast drawn it.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: My dear master, My captain and my emperor, let me say, Before I strike this bloody stroke, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: 'Tis said, man, and farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Farewell, great chief. Shall I strike now?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Now, Eros.

dialogues.speaker: Eros
dialogues.line: Why, there then!  Thus do I escape the sorrow Of Antony's death.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Thrice nobler than myself! Thou teachest me, O valiant Eros, what I should and thou couldst not. My queen and Eros Have by their brave instruction got upon me A nobleness in record. But I will be A bridegroom in my death and run into't As to a lover's bed. Come then, and, Eros, Thy master dies thy scholar. To do thus I learned of thee. How? Not dead? Not dead? The guard, ho! O, dispatch me!

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: What's the noise?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I have done my work ill, friends. O, make an end Of what I have begun.

dialogues.speaker: Second Guard
dialogues.line: The star is fallen.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: And time is at his period.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Alas, and woe!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Let him that loves me strike me dead.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: Not I.

dialogues.speaker: Second Guard
dialogues.line: Nor I.

dialogues.speaker: Third Guard
dialogues.line: Nor anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Dercetus
dialogues.line: Thy death and fortunes bid thy followers fly. This sword but shown to Caesar with this tidings, Shall enter me with him.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Where's Antony?

dialogues.speaker: Dercetus
dialogues.line: There, Diomed, there.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Lives he? Wilt thou not answer, man?

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Art thou there, Diomed? Draw thy sword and give me Sufficing strokes for death.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Most absolute lord, My mistress Cleopatra sent me to thee.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: When did she send thee?

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Now, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: Locked in her monument. She had a prophesying fear Of what hath come to pass. For when she saw- Which never shall be found-you did suspect She had disposed with Caesar, and that your rage Would not be purged, she sent you word she was dead; But fearing since how it might work, hath sent Me to proclaim the truth, and I am come, I dread, too late.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Too late, good Diomed. Call my guard, I prithee.

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: What, ho! The emperor's guard! The guard, what ho! Come, your lord calls!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Bear me, good friends, where Cleopatra bides. 'Tis the last service that I shall command you.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: Woe, woe are we, sir, you may not live to wear All your true followers out.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Most heavy day!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Nay, good my fellows, do not please sharp fate To grace it with your sorrows. Bid that welcome Which comes to punish us, and we punish it, Seeming to bear it lightly. Take me up. I have led you oft; carry me now, good friends, And have my thanks for all.

scenes.location: Alexandria. A monument.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O Charmian, I will never go from hence.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Be comforted, dear madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: No, I will not. All strange and terrible events are welcome, But comforts we despise. Our size of sorrow, Proportioned to our cause, must be as great As that which makes it. Enter, below Diomedes. How now! Is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Diomedes
dialogues.line: His death's upon him, but not dead. Look out o' th' other side your monument; His guard have brought him thither. Enter, below Antony borne by the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O sun, Burn the great sphere thou mov'st in! Darkling stand The varying shore o' th' world. O Antony, Antony, Antony! Help, Charmian! Help, Iras, help! Help, friends below! Let's draw him hither.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Peace! Not Caesar's valour hath o'erthrown Antony, But Antony's hath triumphed on itself.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: So it should be, that none but Antony Should conquer Antony, but woe 'tis so!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I am dying, Egypt, dying. Only I here importune death awhile until Of many thousand kisses the poor last I lay upon thy lips.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I dare not, dear Dear my lord, pardon. I dare not, Lest I be taken. Not th' imperious show Of the full-fortuned Caesar ever shall Be brooched with me; if knife, drugs, serpents, have Edge, sting, or operation, I am safe. Your wife Octavia, with her modest eyes And still conclusion, shall acquire no honour Demuring upon me. But come, come, Antony- Help me, my women-we must draw thee up. Assist, good friends.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: O, quick, or I am gone.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Here's sport indeed! How heavy weighs my lord! Our strength is all gone into heaviness; That makes the weight. Had I great Juno's power, The strong-winged Mercury should fetch thee up And set thee by Jove's side. Yet come a little; Wishers were ever fools. O come, come come, And welcome, welcome! Die where thou hast lived; Quicken with kissing. Had my lips that power, Thus would I wear them out.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: A heavy sight!

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: I am dying, Egypt, dying. Give me some wine, and let me speak a little.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: No, let me speak, and let me rail so high That the false huswife Fortune break her wheel, Provoked by my offence.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: One word, sweet queen: Of Caesar seek your honour, with your safety. O!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: They do not go together.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: Gentle, hear me. None about Caesar trust but Proculeius.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: My resolution and my hands I'll trust; None about Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Antony
dialogues.line: The miserable change now at my end Lament nor sorrow at, but please your thoughts In feeding them with those my former fortunes Wherein I lived the greatest prince o' th' world, The noblest; and do now not basely die, Not cowardly put off my helmet to My countryman; a Roman by a Roman Valiantly vanquished. Now my spirit is going; I can no more.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Noblest of men, woo't die? Hast thou no care of me? Shall I abide In this dull world, which in thy absence is No better than a sty? O, see, my women, The crown o' th' earth doth melt.-My lord! O, withered is the garland of the war, The soldier's pole is fallen; young boys and girls Are level now with men. The odds is gone, And there is nothing left remarkable Beneath the visiting moon.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: O, quietness, lady!

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: She is dead too, our sovereign.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Lady!

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Madam!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: O madam, madam, madam!

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Royal Egypt, Empress!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Peace, peace, Iras!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: No more but e'en a woman, and commanded By such poor passion as the maid that milks And does the meanest chares. It were for me To throw my sceptre at the injurious gods, To tell them that this world did equal theirs Till they had stolen our jewel. All's but naught; Patience is sottish, and impatience does Become a dog that's mad. Then is it sin To rush into the secret house of death Ere death dare come to us? How do you, women? What, what! good cheer! Why, how now, Charmian? My noble girls! Ah, women, women! Look, Our lamp is spent, it's out! Good sirs, take heart. We'll bury him; and then, what's brave, what's noble, Let's do it after the high Roman fashion And make death proud to take us. Come, away. This case of that huge spirit now is cold. Ah, women, women! Come, we have no friend But resolution and the briefest end.

scenes.location: Caesar's Camp before Alexandria.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield. Being so frustrate, tell him, he mocks The pauses that he makes.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Caesar, I shall.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Wherefore is that? And what art thou that dar'st Appear thus to us?

dialogues.speaker: Dercetus
dialogues.line: I am called Dercetus. Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy Best to be served. Whilst he stood up and spoke, He was my master, and I wore my life To spend upon his haters. If thou please To take me to thee, as I was to him I'll be to Caesar; if thou pleasest not, I yield thee up my life.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: What is't thou say'st?

dialogues.speaker: Dercetus
dialogues.line: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: The breaking of so great a thing should make A greater crack. The round world Should have shook lions into civil streets, And citizens to their dens. The death of Antony Is not a single doom; in the name lay A moiety of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Dercetus
dialogues.line: He is dead, Caesar, Not by a public minister of justice, Nor by a hired knife, but that self hand Which writ his honour in the acts it did Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it, Splitted the heart. This is his sword. I robbed his wound of it. Behold it stained With his most noble blood.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Look you sad, friends? The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings To wash the eyes of kings.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: And strange it is That nature must compel us to lament Our most persisted deeds.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: His taints and honours Waged equal with him.

dialogues.speaker: Agrippa
dialogues.line: A rarer spirit never Did steer humanity, but you gods will give us Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touched.

dialogues.speaker: Maecenas
dialogues.line: When such a spacious mirror's set before him, He needs must see himself.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: O Antony, I have followed thee to this, but we do lance Diseases in our bodies. I must perforce Have shown to thee such a declining day Or look on thine. We could not stall together In the whole world. But yet let me lament With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts, That thou, my brother, my competitor In top of all design, my mate in empire, Friend and companion in the front of war, The arm of mine own body, and the heart Where mine his thoughts did kindle, that our stars, Unreconciliable, should divide Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends- But I will tell you at some meeter season. The business of this man looks out of him; We'll hear him what he says. Whence are you?

dialogues.speaker: Egyptian
dialogues.line: A poor Egyptian yet. The queen, my mistress, Confined in all she has, her monument, Of thy intents desires instruction, That she preparedly may frame herself To the way she's forced to.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Bid her have good heart. She soon shall know of us, by some of ours, How honourable and how kindly we Determine for her. For Caesar cannot lean To be ungentle.

dialogues.speaker: Egyptian
dialogues.line: So the gods preserve thee!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say We purpose her no shame. Give her what comforts The quality of her passion shall require, Lest, in her greatness, by some mortal stroke She do defeat us, for her life in Rome Would be eternal in our triumph. Go, And with your speediest bring us what she says And how you find of her.

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: Caesar, I shall.
