dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Gallus, go you along. Where's Dolabella, to second Proculeius?

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Dolabella!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Let him alone, for I remember now How he's employed. He shall in time be ready. Go with me to my tent, where you shall see How hardly I was drawn into this war, How calm and gentle I proceeded still In all my writings. Go with me and see What I can show in this.

scenes.location: Alexandria. A Room in the Monument.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: My desolation does begin to make A better life. 'Tis paltry to be Caesar; Not being Fortune, he's but Fortune's knave, A minister of her will. And it is great To do that thing that ends all other deeds, Which shackles accidents and bolts up change, Which sleeps and never palates more the dung, The beggar's nurse and Caesar's.

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: Caesar sends greetings to the queen of Egypt, And bids thee study on what fair demands Thou mean'st to have him grant thee.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What's thy name?

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: My name is Proculeius.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Antony Did tell me of you, bade me trust you, but I do not greatly care to be deceived That have no use for trusting. If your master Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him That majesty, to keep decorum, must No less beg than a kingdom. If he please To give me conquered Egypt for my son, He gives me so much of mine own as I Will kneel to him with thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: Be of good cheer. You are fallen into a princely hand; fear nothing. Make your full reference freely to my lord, Who is so full of grace that it flows over On all that need. Let me report to him Your sweet dependency, and you shall find A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness Where he for grace is kneeled to.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Pray you tell him I am his fortune's vassal and I send him The greatness he has got. I hourly learn A doctrine of obedience, and would gladly Look him i' th' face.

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: This I'll report, dear lady. Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied Of him that caused it. You see how easily she may be surprised. Guard her till Caesar come.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Royal queen!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: O Cleopatra, thou art taken, queen!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Quick, quick, good hands.

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: Hold, worthy lady, hold! Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this Relieved, but not betrayed.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What, of death too, That rids our dogs of languish?

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: Cleopatra, Do not abuse my master's bounty by Th' undoing of yourself. Let the world see His nobleness well acted, which your death Will never let come forth.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Where art thou, Death? Come hither, come! Come, come, and take a queen Worth many babes and beggars!

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: O, temperance, lady!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Sir, I will eat no meat; I'll not drink, sir; If idle talk will once be necessary, I'll not sleep neither. This mortal house I'll ruin, Do Caesar what he can. Know, sir, that I Will not wait pinioned at your master's court, Nor once be chastised with the sober eye Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up And show me to the shouting varletry Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt Be gentle grave unto me! Rather on Nilus' mud Lay me stark-naked, and let the water-flies Blow me into abhorring! Rather make My country's high pyramides my gibbet And hang me up in chains!

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: You do extend These thoughts of horror further than you shall Find cause in Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Proculeius, What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows, And he hath sent for thee. For the queen, I'll take her to my guard.

dialogues.speaker: Proculeius
dialogues.line: So, Dolabella, It shall content me best. Be gentle to her.  To Caesar I will speak what you shall please, If you'll employ me to him.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Say I would die.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Most noble empress, you have heard of me?

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I cannot tell.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Assuredly you know me.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: No matter, sir, what I have heard or known. You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams; Is't not your trick?

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: I understand not, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I dreamt there was an Emperor Antony. O, such another sleep, that I might see But such another man!

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: If it might please you-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: His face was as the heavens, and therein stuck A sun and moon, which kept their course, and lighted The little O, the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Most sovereign creature-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: His legs bestrid the ocean; his reared arm Crested the world; his voice was propertied As all the tuned spheres, and that to friends; But when he meant to quail and shake the orb, He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty, There was no winter in't; an autumn 'twas That grew the more by reaping. His delights Were dolphin-like; they showed his back above The element they lived in. In his livery Walked crowns and crownets; realms and islands were As plates dropped from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Cleopatra-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Think you there was or might be such a man As this I dreamt of?

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Gentle madam, no.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: You lie up to the hearing of the gods! But if there be nor ever were one such, It's past the size of dreaming. Nature wants stuff To vie strange forms with fancy; yet t' imagine An Antony were nature's piece 'gainst fancy, Condemning shadows quite.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Hear me, good madam. Your loss is, as yourself, great; and you bear it As answering to the weight. Would I might never O'ertake pursued success, but I do feel, By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites My very heart at root.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: I thank you, sir. Know you what Caesar means to do with me?

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Nay, pray you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Though he be honourable-

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: He'll lead me, then, in triumph.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Madam, he will. I know it. Flourish. Enter Caesar, Proculeius, Gallus, Maecenas and others of his train.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: Make way there! Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Which is the Queen of Egypt?

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: It is the Emperor, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Arise, you shall not kneel. I pray you, rise. Rise, Egypt.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Sir, the gods Will have it thus. My master and my lord I must obey.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Take to you no hard thoughts. The record of what injuries you did us, Though written in our flesh, we shall remember As things but done by chance.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Sole sir o' th' world, I cannot project mine own cause so well To make it clear, but do confess I have Been laden with like frailties which before Have often shamed our sex.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Cleopatra, know We will extenuate rather than enforce. If you apply yourself to our intents, Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find A benefit in this change; but if you seek To lay on me a cruelty by taking Antony's course, you shall bereave yourself Of my good purposes, and put your children To that destruction which I'll guard them from If thereon you rely. I'll take my leave.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: And may, through all the world. 'Tis yours, and we, Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall Hang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels I am possessed of. 'Tis exactly valued, Not petty things admitted. Where's Seleucus?

dialogues.speaker: Seleucus
dialogues.line: Here, madam.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: This is my treasurer. Let him speak, my lord, Upon his peril, that I have reserved To myself nothing. Speak the truth, Seleucus.

dialogues.speaker: Seleucus
dialogues.line: Madam, I had rather seal my lips Than to my peril speak that which is not.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: What have I kept back?

dialogues.speaker: Seleucus
dialogues.line: Enough to purchase what you have made known.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Nay, blush not, Cleopatra. I approve Your wisdom in the deed.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: See, Caesar! O, behold, How pomp is followed! Mine will now be yours And should we shift estates, yours would be mine. The ingratitude of this Seleucus does Even make me wild. O slave, of no more trust Than love that's hired! What, goest thou back? Thou shalt Go back, I warrant thee! But I'll catch thine eyes Though they had wings. Slave, soulless villain, dog! O rarely base!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Good queen, let us entreat you.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this, That thou vouchsafing here to visit me, Doing the honour of thy lordliness To one so meek, that mine own servant should Parcel the sum of my disgraces by Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar, That I some lady trifles have reserved, Immoment toys, things of such dignity As we greet modern friends withal; and say Some nobler token I have kept apart For Livia and Octavia, to induce Their mediation, must I be unfolded With one that I have bred? The gods! It smites me Beneath the fall I have.  Prithee go hence, Or I shall show the cinders of my spirits Through th' ashes of my chance. Wert thou a man, Thou wouldst have mercy on me.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Forbear, Seleucus.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Be it known that we, the greatest, are misthought For things that others do; and when we fall, We answer others' merits in our name, Are therefore to be pitied.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Cleopatra, Not what you have reserved nor what acknowledged Put we i' th' roll of conquest. Still be't yours; Bestow it at your pleasure, and believe Caesar's no merchant to make prize with you Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheered; Make not your thoughts your prisons. No, dear queen; For we intend so to dispose you as Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed and sleep. Our care and pity is so much upon you That we remain your friend; and so, adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: My master and my lord!

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Not so. Adieu.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: He words me, girls, he words me, that I should not Be noble to myself. But hark thee, Charmian!

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: Finish, good lady. The bright day is done, And we are for the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Hie thee again. I have spoke already, and it is provided. Go put it to the haste.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Madam, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Where's the Queen?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Behold, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Dolabella!

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Madam, as thereto sworn by your command, Which my love makes religion to obey, I tell you this: Caesar through Syria Intends his journey, and within three days You with your children will he send before. Make your best use of this. I have performed Your pleasure and my promise.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Dolabella, I shall remain your debtor.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: I your servant. Adieu, good queen. I must attend on Caesar.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Farewell, and thanks. Now, Iras, what think'st thou? Thou an Egyptian puppet shall be shown In Rome as well as I. Mechanic slaves With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers shall Uplift us to the view. In their thick breaths, Rank of gross diet, shall we be enclouded, And forced to drink their vapour.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: The gods forbid!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Nay, 'tis most certain, Iras. Saucy lictors Will catch at us like strumpets, and scald rhymers Ballad us out o' tune. The quick comedians Extemporally will stage us and present Our Alexandrian revels; Antony Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness I' th' posture of a whore.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: O the good gods!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Nay, that's certain.

dialogues.speaker: Iras
dialogues.line: I'll never see't, for I am sure mine nails Are stronger than mine eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Why, that's the way To fool their preparation and to conquer Their most absurd intents. Now, Charmian! Show me, my women, like a queen. Go fetch My best attires. I am again for Cydnus To meet Mark Antony. Sirrah, Iras, go. Now, noble Charmian, we'll dispatch indeed, And when thou hast done this chare, I'll give thee leave To play till doomsday. Bring our crown and all. Wherefore's this noise?

dialogues.speaker: Guardsman
dialogues.line: Here is a rural fellow That will not be denied your highness' presence. He brings you figs.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Let him come in. What poor an instrument May do a noble deed! He brings me liberty. My resolution's placed, and I have nothing Of woman in me. Now from head to foot I am marble-constant. Now the fleeting moon No planet is of mine.

dialogues.speaker: Guardsman
dialogues.line: This is the man.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Avoid, and leave him. Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there That kills and pains not?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Truly, I have him, but I would not be the party that should desire you to touch him, for his biting is immortal. Those that do die of it do seldom or never recover.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Remember'st thou any that have died on't?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of them no longer than yesterday-a very honest woman, but something given to lie; as a woman should not do but in the way of honesty-how she died of the biting of it, what pain she felt. Truly she makes a very good report o' th' worm; but he that will believe all that they say shall never be saved by half that they do. But this is most falliable, the worm's an odd worm.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Get thee hence. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: I wish you all joy of the worm.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: You must think this, look you, that the worm will do his kind.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Ay, ay, farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the keeping of wise people; for indeed there is no goodness in the worm.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Take thou no care; it shall be heeded.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you, for it is not worth the feeding.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Will it eat me?

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: You must not think I am so simple but I know the devil himself will not eat a woman. I know that a woman is a dish for the gods if the devil dress her not. But truly, these same whoreson devils do the gods great harm in their women, for in every ten that they make, the devils mar five.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Well, get thee gone. Farewell.

dialogues.speaker: Clown
dialogues.line: Yes, forsooth. I wish you joy o' th' worm. Enter Iras with a robe, crown, &c.

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Give me my robe. Put on my crown. I have Immortal longings in me. Now no more The juice of Egypt's grape shall moist this lip. Yare, yare, good Iras; quick. Methinks I hear Antony call. I see him rouse himself To praise my noble act. I hear him mock The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men To excuse their after wrath. Husband, I come! Now to that name my courage prove my title! I am fire and air; my other elements I give to baser life.-So, have you done? Come then, and take the last warmth of my lips. Farewell, kind Charmian. Iras, long farewell. Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall? If thou and nature can so gently part, The stroke of death is as a lover's pinch, Which hurts and is desired. Dost thou lie still? If thus thou vanishest, thou tell'st the world It is not worth leave-taking.

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain, that I may say The gods themselves do weep!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: This proves me base. If she first meet the curled Antony, He'll make demand of her, and spend that kiss Which is my heaven to have.-Come, thou mortal wretch, With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate Of life at once untie. Poor venomous fool, Be angry and dispatch. O couldst thou speak, That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass Unpolicied!

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: O eastern star!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: Peace, peace! Dost thou not see my baby at my breast That sucks the nurse asleep?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: O, break! O, break!

dialogues.speaker: Cleopatra
dialogues.line: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle- O Antony!-Nay, I will take thee too. What should I stay-

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: In this vile world? So, fare thee well. Now boast thee, Death, in thy possession lies A lass unparalleled. Downy windows, close, And golden Phœbus never be beheld Of eyes again so royal! Your crown's awry; I'll mend it and then play.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: Where's the queen?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Speak softly. Wake her not.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: Caesar hath sent-

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: Too slow a messenger. O, come apace, dispatch! I partly feel thee.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: Approach, ho! All's not well. Caesar's beguiled.

dialogues.speaker: Second Guard
dialogues.line: There's Dolabella sent from Caesar. Call him.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: What work is here, Charmian? Is this well done?

dialogues.speaker: Charmian
dialogues.line: It is well done, and fitting for a princess Descended of so many royal kings. Ah, soldier!

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: How goes it here?

dialogues.speaker: Second Guard
dialogues.line: All dead.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Caesar, thy thoughts Touch their effects in this. Thyself art coming To see performed the dreaded act which thou So sought'st to hinder.

dialogues.speaker: All
dialogues.line: A way there, a way for Caesar!

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: O sir, you are too sure an augurer: That you did fear is done.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Bravest at the last, She levelled at our purposes and, being royal, Took her own way. The manner of their deaths? I do not see them bleed.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Who was last with them?

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: A simple countryman that brought her figs. This was his basket.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Poisoned then.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: O Caesar, This Charmian lived but now; she stood and spake. I found her trimming up the diadem On her dead mistress; tremblingly she stood, And on the sudden dropped.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: O noble weakness! If they had swallowed poison 'twould appear By external swelling; but she looks like sleep, As she would catch another Antony In her strong toil of grace.

dialogues.speaker: Dolabella
dialogues.line: Here on her breast There is a vent of blood, and something blown. The like is on her arm.

dialogues.speaker: First Guard
dialogues.line: This is an aspic's trail, and these fig leaves Have slime upon them, such as th' aspic leaves Upon the caves of Nile.

dialogues.speaker: Caesar
dialogues.line: Most probable That so she died, for her physician tells me She hath pursued conclusions infinite Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed, And bear her women from the monument. She shall be buried by her Antony. No grave upon the earth shall clip in it A pair so famous. High events as these Strike those that make them; and their story is No less in pity than his glory which Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall In solemn show attend this funeral, And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see High order in this great solemnity.
